name: La Présidente. –
text: The agenda calls for debate on the Commission's declaration on the participation of disabled people in the European elections (2018/2647 (RSP)).

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, thank you for tabling this issue on the agenda of the plenary of the European Parliament. We often discuss the European elections these days and this debate gives us the opportunity to emphasise that the right to vote, both in law and in reality, should be enjoyed by everyone. This was clearly spelled out in the European Disability Strategy for the years 2010-2020. In addition, in the 2017 Citizenship Report, the Commission prioritised the promotion of citizens’ participation in the democratic life of the EU, including that of vulnerable groups, such as persons with disabilities. The data available shows that, given the opportunity, people with disabilities actively participate in politics. Let me recall from the outset that the practical organisation of elections in the EU Member States, including the rules that apply to people with disabilities, falls within the competence of each Member State in compliance with EU law. For its part, the Commission actively promotes the identification and exchange of best practices in order to enhance the participation of persons with disabilities in elections. The Commission also highlighted this issue in its recent recommendation on enhancing the European nature and efficient conduct of the 2019 European elections. Let me also refer to the Commission’s 2018 report on local elections, which examined the policies of the Member States to support turnout among under—represented groups, including persons with disabilities. Good practices include Braille templates for the ballot paper, audio recorders at polling booths and the possibility of early voting, as well as voting in retirement homes and hospitals. The Commission will continue to use its network of Member State experts in electoral matters to identify and promote best practices in this area, as it did in April this year. The Commission has also launched a study on remote voting solutions. In addition, the Commission has given funding to several EU—level disability organisations in order to collect information on barriers to voting, including the experiences of persons with intellectual disabilities.  I very much look forward to this debate.

name: Agnieszka Kozłowska-Rajewicz
text: On behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Dear! Participation in elections, both passive and active, is one of the key acts of democracy and a fundamental civil right. It is the duty of every democratic state to ensure that all citizens entitled to vote, regardless of their fitness, can participate in elections. Unfortunately, despite years and technological developments, disability is very often associated with an indirect restriction of citizens' rights, because due to the lack of accessibility to polling stations or the lack of procedures that make it easier to reach polling stations or read ballot papers, voting becomes difficult or impossible. In Poland, the Civic Platform government introduced changes to the electoral law in 2011, which, in addition to the obligation to ensure the availability of premises and various facilities for persons with disabilities – for example, the preparation of braille overlays – also enabled postal voting. It was thought primarily of the elderly and disabled, but in the end this form of voting was made available to all who need it and report it in good time. Currently, this possibility of postal voting is limited only to a group of persons with disabilities, which greatly complicates the system and stigmatizes those using this form of voting.  Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for Correspondent voting is available in at least 20 countries in the European Union. It is used by a large proportion of the voting population, including people with disabilities. However, we need much broader changes and I would like, above all, to thank you very much for all the initiatives that you mentioned at the beginning of the debate. It is important that we work on this issue, and I would like to ask what tools the Commission has at its disposal to influence the Member States, so that elections are more inclusive not only in terms of the exercise of the law, but also in terms of how widely the law covers citizens entitled to vote.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Madam President, 51% of people with disabilities are involved in political life, compared to 48% of people without disabilities. 82% of persons with disabilities who can exercise the right to vote do so, compared to 51% of the population without disabilities. This is true of hundreds of thousands of people with disabilities in the European Union who are limited and cannot exercise this right to vote because of their legal incapacitation. Only seven Member States guarantee the right to vote in all cases to persons with disabilities and only eight Member States have defined strategies to promote the participation of persons with disabilities in political life. All this against article 12 and article 29 of the United Nations Convention, which calls for us to remove all physical and also legal barriers and to guarantee the right of these persons to participate in public life. I therefore ask the European Commission to promote concrete measures for Member States to adapt their respective laws to the United Nations Convention.

name: Helga Stevens
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Mr President, people with disabilities can only participate fully in society if they can also participate in political life like any other EU citizen. There are around 80 million people living in the EU with disabilities, but why do you see them so little in political positions?  People with disabilities still don't get equal opportunities. In the majority of Member States, people with disabilities lose their right to vote if they are declared incapable of action. Fifteen EU Member States automatically deny people with disabilities who are under guardianship their right to vote. There are also major barriers to voting, as electoral offices are often simply not accessible. Only in 12 of the 28 Member States there are accessibility requirements for all electoral offices and where there are already accessibility conditions, they usually focus only on physical accessibility. The information that people with disabilities can receive is also often very limited. Election programmes, debates and meetings are still barely accessible. In a democratic society, everyone must have the right to make an informed choice.  Make no mistake, there is indeed a strong legal framework which obliges the EU and the Member States to ensure that people with disabilities can participate in political life on an equal basis as any other citizen. Unfortunately, the reality is just disappointing. It is high time that this was finally changed.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, Commissioner, the European institutions are linked to the contents of the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, and so are the signatory States.  It is up to us, in the face of the forthcoming elections, to live up to the commitments and promises that emerged last December from the Fourth European Parliament of Persons with Disabilities. More decision and leadership was called for to make rights that are clear about the role and over which there is no opposition between parties and organizations into reality; ultimately depend on the political will to lead the commitment to allocate means and resources, and the effort to change cultures that contradict the contents of the Convention.  It should be recalled that, in article 29, the Convention guarantees persons with disabilities political rights and the possibility of enjoying them on an equal footing with others. To this end, it makes commitments on full and effective participation in political life on an equal footing and, of course, the right and possibility of persons with disabilities to vote and be elected.  The forthcoming European elections should be an example of adapting electoral procedures, facilities and materials to the needs of persons with disabilities. They should mark a milestone in accessibility and encourage a movement to stimulate the presence of more and new disability representatives on electoral rolls.  According to existing data, one in six people over the age of fifteen suffers from some form of disability in the Union. Their functional diversity makes them different, but not unequal; they have a lot to teach us. And there is no better way to work this necessary empathy than to have them around, listen to them every day and learn that what we often consider normal — a ladder, a faucet, a combination of colors — for many Europeans is a real wall.

name: Tilly Metz
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Madam President, I will indeed talk about the participation and voting rights of people with disabilities.  According to the UN convention, people with disabilities are people with long-term physical, psychological, cognitive, mental or sensory disabilities. The opportunity to participate in political life is at the heart of what defines a democratic Europe. All too often, legal and administrative barriers prevent people with disabilities from accessing information. In fact, one in six people in the European Union has a disability. As a result, this prevents them from actively participating in society.  I would like to highlight here some elements that promote the participation of all citizens. Accessibility to the polling station must of course be ensured, i.e. ramps, elevators and, if necessary, attendants must be provided. But before that, we need to make political programmes accessible to all, that is, translating them into Braille for the visually impaired, translating them into simplified language with pictograms for people with cognitive impairments and, in a speech, systematically guaranteeing a sign language translation for people with hearing loss - and I hope there is one. Another problem is guardianship. In principle, people under guardianship do not have the right to vote and I would like to quote Josef Schovanec, an autistic person, writer and philosopher: "It is completely abnormal to have to go to court to have the right to put a ballot in the ballot box when we see the vote of certain people who are supposed to be sane". "Design for all" must also apply to European elections. In other words, everyone must be ensured that the policy is accessible and attractive. It also means meeting all voters, and not waiting for them to come to you.  A final important aspect, in the context of the disability empowerment movement, is to encourage them to engage themselves in politics, in order to move the situation towards a much more inclusive society. That way, we would definitely stop talking about people with disabilities and talk more with them.

name: Ángela Vallina
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, there are some seventy million people in the European Union who suffer from some form of disability. The United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities provides, in article 12, for equal recognition before the law and, in 29, participation in the public life of persons with disabilities, including the right to vote and to be elected and elected. We must ensure the non-discrimination of these people, both in the European elections and in the elections of each of our Member States. In Spain, for example, there have been criticisms from a number of organizations and institutions, as, as the United Nations has found, there are still serious shortcomings in the implementation of the Convention, especially with regard to persons with mental disabilities. I therefore call for us to move forward at all levels and in all administrations, adapting legal systems, removing administrative barriers and facilitating complaint mechanisms in order to vote. Only in this way can we take effective steps towards true equal rights.

name: Isabella Adinolfi
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, the issue of the participation of people with disabilities in European elections is of great importance. But there is still much to be done to make the rights of those who have been less fortunate and suffering from a disability effective. Over and above declarations of principle, concrete action is needed, otherwise there is a risk that the rights enshrined in the constitutions of the various Member States and in the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union will remain a dead letter. All citizens are equal and have equal dignity. I would like to take this opportunity to launch a proposal: having dealt with electronic democracy and the use of digital tools, I believe that the time is ripe for implementing forms of electronic participation, such as online voting, which would make it much easier for people with disabilities to participate politically. In this respect, I wonder whether the Commission has already prepared concrete initiatives along these lines, perhaps taking as its starting point some Member States that are particularly at the forefront, such as Estonia. I am convinced that the use of electronic tools can be an element of help for those who want to participate actively in political life and who have a disability. Next year's European elections are an opportunity not to be wasted on the European Union, to demonstrate that guaranteeing and effectively implementing the rights of people with disabilities is a priority. For my part, I will continue to fight hard for these rights to be guaranteed in practice.

name: Gilles Lebreton
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Madam President, people with disabilities are entitled to political participation. This right is guaranteed by several legal instruments, including the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. This right to participation must therefore also be exercised in the European elections. Several measures need to be taken, including the accessibility of polling stations, which is far from effective at present. More generally, there is a need to raise public and government awareness of the need to do everything possible to ensure that disabled people have real equality in electoral matters. This equality means that a disabled person must not only be able to vote, but also stand for election, if he wishes. On the other hand, I do not want a quota system, as Tunisia has just done for municipal elections. Tunisia requires that each list of candidates includes at least one disabled person. Such a system may seem generous, but it is contrary to equality before the vote. Moreover, it is likely to hinder democracy by preventing candidates from running for office if they have failed to persuade a disabled person to join them. Every way must be done to ensure equality, but with strict respect for democracy.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE).
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank the European I was elected to the European Parliament in 2009 as the first desicn Member. Since then, it has been my heart to make sure that as many people with disabilities as possible can exercise their right to vote, no matter what type of choice. At the same time, as many people with disabilities as possible are elected to political bodies. This framework should be provided by electoral legislation in accordance with the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities.  I am proud that my country, Hungary, has completely made elections accessible, whether blind, deaf or disabled, with the new electoral legislation adopted in 2013. Hungary is the only country in the European Union where desicable members have been elected to the Parliament and the European Parliament. However, only one party, the Fidesz-KDNP, provided this opportunity to persons with disabilities or politicians.  It is time to prove it not only through legislation, but also through action.  I hereby call on all parties running in elections to the European Parliament in the EU-27 to give people with disabilities a meaningful opportunity. Thank you!

name: Olga Sehnalová (S&D).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, we often complain about low turnout and people's lack of interest in elections. There are citizens who would like to come to the polls to express their opinion, but for all sorts of reasons this is not possible for them. They're people with disabilities. There are 80 million citizens with disabilities in the European Union, yet they are hardly represented in public life at all, nor do political party programmes think much about them.  It is not only enough to make polling stations accessible in order to allow them to participate fully in elections. For a responsible choice, it is also necessary to have enough information. Unfortunately, the materials of political parties and their programmes are mostly not available in formats that a person with a disability could read, which limits not only his right to vote, but also the possibilities of actively participating in political life.  The right to vote is as important for people with disabilities as it is for everyone else, and we should therefore make sure that they are not second-class citizens either at the next Elections to the European Parliament or at any other time.

name: Anthea McIntyre (ECR).
text: – Madam President, last month I was honoured to lead a delegation from the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs (EMPL) of this Parliament to the United Nations in New York for the 11th session of the Conference of State Parties to the Convention of the Rights of Persons with Disabilities (CRPD). The EU is officially represented in the CRPD by the Commission, so this was the first time that Members of the European Parliament, the directly elected representatives of citizens across Europe, participated in the event.  I was particularly pleased to listen to my EMPL colleague, Ádám Kósa, make a powerful speech about the participation of people with disabilities in the political process. In this session entitled ‘Nothing about us without us’, we also learned about the practical steps that some countries are taking to ensure that everyone can vote – mobile polling stations, taking the election to the voter in hospital, portable polling booths that can enable a wheelchair user to cast their vote in private.  As signatories to the Convention, the EU has a responsibility to ensure that everyone can participate in the electoral process.

name: Κωνσταντίνα Κούνεβα (GUE/NGL).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, every five years after the European elections we are faced with the same result: less and less participation of citizens in the European elections.  Then there are the analyses of the democratic deficit in Europe. We all know that our Union disappoints citizens in many ways, but people with disabilities are not just disappointed, we are effectively excluded from the European elections and we are at least 10% of the electorate.  What democracy is it that deprives the blind, the deaf, the paraplegic the right to be informed in an appropriate and understandable way, the right to vote or to be a candidate? It's a crippled democracy. Gentlemen of the Commission, a few months ago, as the Committee on Petitions, we asked you a specific question about the measures you will take from the very next European elections, so as not to deprive any disabled citizen of the right to be elected and elected. I must say that what I have heard so far is not very encouraging.  The participation of the disabled in elections must become a criterion of the quality of our democracy and begin to be measured by the coming European elections. We have all the technological means. yes, it's going to cost. Indeed, democracy is an expensive system, but it is the best we have.

name: Marek Plura (PPE).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Honourable Commissioner, I would like to thank you for your excellent work. Dear colleagues, I would like to thank you for your excellent work. I am pleased that we are taking up the issue of the availability of European elections today, and I believe that we will continue to debate this important issue. The UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities commits to providing the conditions for the full participation of persons with disabilities in political and social life on an equal level playing field with others. Unfortunately, in many countries, the reality deviates from the convention. Discrimination on the basis of disability is contrary to the principles on which the European Union is built and not only shames us, but also wastes the enormous social and economic potential of 80 million Europeans. During this parliamentary term, the European Parliament has worked on a number of regulations to enable persons with disabilities to exercise their rights. In December, we had the honour of hosting the European Parliament for People with Disabilities, which was attended by several hundred representatives from all over Europe. We have heard many extremely moving testimonies of violations of their rights, as well as a manifesto aimed at European leaders to make the European elections widely available and non-discriminatory. This is a commitment that I, my colleagues at Disability Intergroup and other Members with President Antoni Tajani at the helm take very seriously. Dear colleagues, I would like to thank you for your excellent work. It is not enough to declare that people with disabilities have the right to vote and stand as candidates. Conditions must be created for them to exercise this right. Appropriate specific guidelines must be addressed to the Member States and good practices exchanged. I therefore propose the start of a working cycle of meetings to develop them, and I declare my full commitment to such activities.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: – Although the right of persons with disabilities to vote and to be elected is enshrined in the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, to which not only the European Union but also individual Member States have subscribed, this right is still not a matter of course everywhere. I am very pleased that the Constitutional Court in Slovakia last year also granted people deprived of legal capacity the right to vote. However, there remain concerns among some of these people as to whether they will reach the ballot box and be free to decide who will assist them in exercising their right to vote. Despite this positive step, many people with disabilities still do not get to the polling station because of the barriers. For the same reasons, they cannot be members of electoral commissions. It is also not a matter of course that pre-election debates or electoral programmes are available to people with hearing or visual impairments, that the materials are accessible, easy to understand and usable. It is important to break down not only physical barriers, but also psychological ones. So that even people with disabilities who choose to run have a chance of being elected. Their active presence in political decision-making is important, beneficial and rewarding, and in particular is their fundamental right.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, Article 14 of the European Convention on Human Rights demands human rights without discrimination. The Equality and Human Rights Commission recently echoed the views of the UN and stated that persons with disabilities continue to face an onslaught against their rights in Britain and in the north of Ireland. This includes the right to participate in public life. In order to uphold this right, elections have to be accessible. Member States need to ensure that election registration and all communications are totally accessible: polling stations need to be equipped to facilitate persons with reduced mobility; postal and proxy votes should be available everywhere; and every impediment to disabled candidates putting themselves forward for election should be removed. The EU should focus on this, and not on transnational list nonsense or undemocratic thresholds. Brexit makes matters worse for us. Brexit will mean the loss of the EU representation and rights for persons with disability and threatens funding for support services, infrastructure and carers. GUE/NGL and Sinn Féin will continue to fight for a rights-based society, and on a separate note, that includes the rights of the interpreters who are on strike around us here.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, there is no doubt that we can all agree that active and passive voting rights for persons with disabilities guarantee many international conventions, article 29 of the UN Convention has been cited here.  We also undoubtedly agree, as is clear from the debate, that the Member States should, above all, take measures to make it easier for all persons with disabilities to exercise their political rights at the, say, reasonable level that guarantees the availability of that right. This is mainly an adjustment of electoral procedures, it is about the availability of a polling station. Of course, also about the availability of materials that are linked to the exercise of that right to vote in relation precisely to national elections, but also, of course, to elections to the European Parliament.  The keyword is barrier-free. So we have already talked about polling stations, which should of course be accessible to all persons with disabilities. Electoral procedures, including remote voting, should also be accessible and fully understandable to persons with disabilities. Then there are the measures that concern the Member States and the political parties. The availability of pre-election material in sign language, in those other aids that simply make it easier for these people to have access to these materials, is, I think, very important and has already been mentioned here.  Election debates should also be interpreted in this way for people with disabilities. Equal quotas have already been mentioned here, and I would also like to say that. I am not in support of the application of quotas, but there is no doubt that Member States should encourage political parties running for their territory to put them in the elective seats.

name: Julie Ward (S&D).
text: – Madam President, the European Disability Forum, representing the voices of people with disabilities across Europe, has adopted a manifesto for the participation of persons with disabilities in the European elections. The manifesto gives recommendations that would ensure that people with disabilities can enjoy their right to vote and stand for election. I invite colleagues from all political groups to read the manifesto and answer the call by integrating the recommendations into their election campaign commitments and pledges. Meanwhile, the constant effort to improve the participation of people with disabilities in political and civil life should not limit itself to election periods. The active citizenship of all citizens must remain a priority in our increasingly fragile democracies. The most efficient way to ensure equal opportunities, accessibility, non-discrimination and social justice for all is to maintain a human rights approach, as well as to further involve civil society and those directly affected in the decision—making processes. In that respect, I call on the Commission to reinstate the funding for the European Network on Independent Living.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Madam President, participation in the democratic life of the Union must be guaranteed to all citizens, especially in the context of the European elections. And that's much more true for people with disabilities. Moreover, the UN Convention, in Articles 12 and 29, stipulates that persons with disabilities must and must have the same rights as other citizens. Of course, the participation process means, among other things, that people with disabilities should be able to participate in the process of the exchange of views themselves in the context of the European elections. Secondly, to have access to the political programmes of the parties. Thirdly, to be able to have this access in a special way, such as the Braille system.  In addition, it must be ensured that disabled people have access to the polling stations themselves in order to be able to vote. This also presupposes that they have unsanced access to public transport. We know a number of countries, because of the petitions that have come to our Commission, where there is no possibility of traffic, of transporting people, especially by rail. These are all important issues that we must take into account. Also use e-democracy to be able to vote online, as well as the practice of letter voting.

name: Cécile Kashetu Kyenge (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, thank you for these answers, which are now more important than ever. The Europe of equality, non-discrimination, accessibility and the protection of human rights, the founding values of our institutions, starts with the election of the representatives of this Parliament and starts from the way in which we will implement measures aimed at raising awareness and encouraging direct representation of people with disabilities within our institutions. This path must necessarily involve improving the ability to provide information accessible to all. Unfortunately, there remains a fundamental problem: the great difficulty in removing architectural barriers, which even today too many citizens with disabilities face every day. We must talk not only about guarantees of autonomous access to voting, but also about guarantees that will enable daily life to overcome barriers that damage not only the autonomy, but also the dignity of individuals and which deny them full exercise their right to vote.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, in this House today we are debating two fundamental rights for each country that really wants to call itself civil: that of democratic participation and that of equality of people with disabilities, principles that the UN recognises but which, nevertheless, we are here to call for. We are here to ask you what the state of what has been an obstacle course for several legislatures is. Because these are not only physical barriers in many cases, but also ideological, communicative and bureaucratic barriers. On the eve of the next European elections, we note that people with disabilities are still practically excluded from voting rights in some Member States of this Europe. Commissioner, there is no more time for discussion: there is an urgent need for uniform legislation, immediate measures, effective corrective measures to implement every step of the European disability strategy. We ask you out loud: it is a political, ethical and moral duty.

name: Monika Beňová (S&D)
text: – It is not only for participation or voting in the Euro elections that people with disabilities do not expect our regret. They need concrete steps to make it easier for them to overcome the obstacles they encounter on a daily basis. People with disabilities are a full part of our society. In matters relating to the forthcoming elections and the increase in the participation of disabled fellow citizens, this is not only an opportunity to vote, but also an active use of their right to stand as a vote. In this case, the European Commission must therefore also think about people with disabilities. You should prepare a large-scale incentive campaign so that they can run more easily and directly compete for citizens' votes if they are interested. You should have at your disposal a sufficient amount of information material, customized websites or specialized printed matter. These must be freely available in different formats and must also be comprehensible and easy to read, for example in braille. It is very important that we involve our fellow citizens – and especially the disabled – as actively as possible in everyday life, including their participation in elections.

name: Κώστας Μαυρίδης (S&D).
text: Madam President, the right of persons with disabilities to participate in the whole political process leading to the right to vote and to stand as a candidate is a fundamental right for all citizens in a democracy. People with mobility disabilities, with reduced visibility, with psychosocial disabilities, persons in custody, who are confined and locked up, are certainly deprived of the right to vote, but even more so are deprived of the right to participate effectively in a democracy. That is why, if so many millions are deprived of this fundamental right, it means that democracy itself is crippled.  That is why I come up with a phrase which I think presents the issue in its essence: the right to participate in the whole electoral process of voting and to stand as a candidate in a democracy is also a question of dignity.

name: Krzysztof Hetman (PPE).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Honourable Commissioner, I would like to thank you for your excellent work. Colleagues, i would like to thank you for your excellent work. People with disabilities, who make up almost 20% of all citizens of the European Union, face a number of barriers, both physical, mental and regulatory, that make them often choose not to participate in elections. It's time to change that. As a signatory to the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, the European Union has committed itself to ensure the inclusion and active participation of persons with disabilities in society. In order to make a real difference and give all people with disabilities the opportunity to vote next year, decisive action is needed among all decision-makers not only at European level, but also at national and local level. Ensuring the availability of polling stations or the possibility of postal or online voting are important issues that must nevertheless be implemented within the Member States. However, the European Union should monitor, support, coordinate and provide adequate know-how to improve the implementation of these tasks.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, a famous Italian singer-songwriter, Giorgio Gaber, said an extraordinary concept in its simplicity and truth: freedom is participation. The possibility of taking part in political life is a central element for all those living in a democratic society. The strongest signal that Europe can give disabled citizens in this respect is to adopt concrete inclusion measures as early as the next election round, which are not limited to awareness-raising activities but go to understand and resolve the obstacles that disabled people encounter in participating in public life. We must start from the information materials on political programmes, which must be available in braille, passing through the requirements for the accessibility of seats, up to voting procedures for those who live in an institution or are unable to move. But it is even more urgent to build a form of active representation of disabled people here in Parliament, encouraging those disabled citizens who represent the values of their community to apply and bring their experience and, above all, other priorities with them to Europe.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE).
text: – In recent years, people with disabilities have increasingly gained seats in both European and Member State parliaments. These were due to their integration into different political parties or their nomination as independents by one party.  It is a welcome development that the various parties, regardless of their political and ideological affiliation, are trying to put people with disabilities in a position, giving them the opportunity to represent citizens with special needs and the increasing presence of these needs in party programmes. I hope that the European Commission will also succeed in proposing measures to support people with disabilities in overcoming voting barriers.  However, in order for the subject to be not only symbolically raised by politics, more measures would be needed to facilitate the daily lives of people with disabilities. Such a measure at European level could be mutual recognition of disability classifications, for example. Thank you.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, I congratulate you for making this statement and saying that it is necessary to have examples of good practice to share. After all, the problem of the integration of people with disabilities is the problem of everyone, of all Member States. There's no shortage of regulations. Sure, we have the UN Convention. We have the constitutions of the Member States. The problem is with the application. I'm a man who worked with the Disability Association. They are responsible people, often much more civically involved than other people, and it is absolutely unfair and immoral to put a barrier in them. I think it is very important to see how we can simplify participation because, very often, because of inadequate infrastructure, people cannot participate. There's been talk here about guardianship. Perhaps you are thinking, Commissioner, of a change in this regulation, too, because, very often, we have met and had concrete discussions: people with disabilities under guardianship are almost in slavery. They claim rights over their lives, not leaving them and not allowing them to participate in civic life. I hope that we will have a fair participation of people with disabilities.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank the honourable Members for their contributions and dedication in promoting the rights of people with disabilities. Let me react on several questions and comments.  First, on legal questions. Both the EU and its Member States are parties to the United Nations Convention, which has to be implemented according to their respective competencies. Council Directives 93/109/EC and 94/80/EC on the electoral rights of mobile EU citizens apply the principle of equality and non-discrimination between nationals and non-nationals in the exercise of the electoral rights associated with EU citizenship.  The Directives as such do not presuppose complete harmonisation of Member States’ electoral systems, which, to a large extent, remain governed by national laws. Also, the Court of Justice confirmed that it is up to EU countries to regulate aspects of European Parliament electoral procedure not harmonised at EU level by the Electoral Act. However, they must respect EU law, including the Charter on Fundamental Rights and the general principles of EU law, which include equality of treatment and non-discrimination.  In saying that the electoral law and the rules fall under the competence of the Member States, the Commission is not declaring that this is not something which we want to work on and which we do not want to support.  You asked, rightly, about what the Commission did, what it does and what it will do. I can only repeat here what I indicated at the beginning – the Commission’s actions support and supplement national policies and programmes to promote political participation and the exercise of the electoral rights of under-represented groups, including persons with disabilities.  The Commission remains committed to enhancing in future reports its assessment of existing election procedures in this area among the Member States. We have already started working on the new strategy after 2020, because I think that it is important to have a proper, solid strategic paper which will cover this very important topic.  Also, last year, the Commission adopted its third report on EU citizenship. It envisages that this year we should promote best practices which help citizens vote and stand in EU elections, including citizens with disabilities. This year, in April, I met the electoral commissioners of all the Member States and we discussed how best to promote the electoral rights of under-represented groups. We didn’t speak about general stuff. We didn’t speak about the use of proclamations. We spoke about those concrete actions and the needs of people with disabilities, which you have mentioned here as well.  This was the first step and this debate with the electoral commissioners will feed into this November’s Colloquium on Fundamental Rights, because we will organise this high-level event on democratic participation with a special focus on increasing the participation of young people and vulnerable and under-represented groups.  As I said, this debate will take place in the framework of the Fundamental Rights Colloquium dedicated to democracy. We organise this colloquium every year. It is open to the public, it is web-streamed. We have very good feedback from the widest possible society. This is not just one of those events where we speak with the same group of people within some bubble. This is a very open event and I very much hope that this will be the right place where we will discuss the possible sharing of best practices, including the possibilities of using digital voting tools and some other concrete measures which the Member States could and should introduce into their system to enable people to take part in the electoral process.  I can assure you that the Commission shares the commitment to promoting the political participation of people with disabilities. I will look into the possibility of using the European Social Fund and some other funding possibilities because I really want this money to serve the best purpose and this is a very important matter. We should also be able to help civil society, helping and working with people with disabilities to open the door to the voting rooms and help them to take part in it.  That was about the right to vote. Now let me touch just briefly upon the right to be voted. I think that we are all members of political parties and we should take it as our homework as well, our personal homework, to go to our political parties and to speak about the need for more diversity.  I am personally involved in several campaigns enhancing the participation of women and the participation of representatives of minorities. I am personally mentoring several very promising young Roma politicians and I think that we have to do the same in our political parties to raise this topic and help people with disabilities get onto candidate lists. I think that diversity, as I said, is very important and we can all do something very concrete, something which can be done today, tomorrow, in our political groups so as to have more people with disabilities participating actively in the elections.

name: La Présidente. –
text: The debate is closed. Written statements (Article 162)

name: Rosa Estaràs Ferragut (PPE)
text: in writing. – Political participation is a right of citizenship recognized to all people. Therefore, persons with disabilities would not have to find any impediment when exercising both their right to participate in political life and their right to vote. These rights are recognized in various international human rights treaties, such as the United Nations Universal Declaration of Human Rights, the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights and the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. Therefore, from the European Union, and in our case from this Parliament, we must work to guarantee these rights, namely the right to information, the right to vote itself, the right to participate in the process and the right to exercise on an equal footing. It is our responsibility to assert these rights to all people, without anyone having obstacles to exercising them, and this is the objective for which we must work.

name: Laura Ferrara (EFDD)
text: in writing. Disability cannot and must not be a restriction on the exercise of the right to vote and stand as a candidate in any type of election, including European elections. We need to go beyond the declarations of principle already contained in the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities and identify actions and instruments that can remove the obstacles that actually prevent particularly vulnerable people, such as the disabled, from actually participating in elections. In this direction, a significant contribution, so as not to leave anyone behind, could come from technologies conceived and designed also at election events and used in order to make full participation by everyone. Innovation, technology and good practice, supported by appropriate legal bases and initiatives also at European and national level, can help to achieve inclusive and accessible elections for all eligible voters.

name: Indrek Tarand (Verts/ALE).
text: – As Vice-President of the European Parliament’s Disability Intergroup, and having been President of the Estonian Union of Persons with Mobility Impairment for four years, I am acutely aware of the obstacles faced by persons with disabilities in their everyday lives. For instance, even a couple of steps in the wrong place can become a significant hurdle if you are in a wheelchair. When it comes to elections, be it European elections or any elections for that matter, we must do our utmost to make the procedures accessible to all persons, including those with disabilities, no matter what kind of impairment they have. It is imperative that these people are not disenfranchised and prevented from exercising their fundamental right of having a say in the democratic process. Since it is not always obvious for everyone to foresee all the accessibility arrangements that need to be made, I recommend to the relevant authorities turn to the organisations representing disabled people, in case of any doubt. It is also important that a sufficient number, if not all of the polling stations are made accessible, especially in countries where online voting is not available, otherwise there is still a risk of a discriminatory effect.

name: La Présidente. –
text: The agenda calls for debate on six motions for a resolution on the political crisis in Moldova following the invalidation of local elections in Chisinau (2018/2783 (RSP)).

name: Cristian Dan Preda
text: Author. – Madam President, my political group has proposed today's debate on the political crisis of proportions that the Republic of Moldova is going through after the abusive annulment of the Chisinau vote. This abuse weakens a rule of law that was, and so, very fragile. (The speaker is interrupted by the President, who announces that there are problems with the translation) Moldovan democracy is in the blackout. I am pleased to see that the political groups, for the most part, have supported the EPP initiative and, as seen in the joint resolution that we will be voting on today, have understood the gravity of the situation. Unfortunately, when, in the last year, I warned that great things were happening in Moldova, I was ignored. The Socialist Group managed through various maneuvers to hide the reality of the Republic of Moldova here, in Strasbourg, or in Brussels. Behind these maneuvers is the Social Democratic Party of Bucharest, which makes the games of the oligarch Plahotniuc. There is no doubt that Plahotniuc and his party are the authors of the decision to annul the local vote held in Chisinau. The decision was not made by the court, but by the oligarch. The annulment of the vote shows us, once again, that the state is taken over by one person and that, in Chisinau, justice is today used to settle political disputes. That's really serious. Moldova is a state captured by an oligarch, who does not want his affairs and his clan in Chisinau to be jeopardized by andrei Nastase's arrival at the town hall. Nastase, the elected mayor, who is with us today in the official stand, is one of the leaders of the pro-European opposition, which has made the fight against corruption and oligarchy a political objective. The citizens supported him, the oligarch blocked him. In this context, I denounce, on behalf of the PPE Group, the annulment of the results of the Chisinau vote, which was made in a non-transparent manner and for purely political reasons. I express my solidarity with all the citizens of the capital of the Republic of Moldova, who took to the streets in large numbers to defend their vote. It's good to keep doing it, to show that the will of the people cannot be trampled. We have to act, too. Events have once again shown us that the preconditions for the provision of macro-financial assistance are far from being met. Therefore, any such payment to the Republic of Moldova must be suspended. Moreover, I also call for an end to European support for the state budget. I believe that no more euros should be sent to Chisinau until the following conditions are met: the validation of the local elections in Chisinau, the holding of credible parliamentary elections, the investigation of bank fraud known as the "theft of the billion" and the return to a rule of law and the start of credible reforms in the field of justice.

name: Charles Tannock
text: author. – Madam President, the decision to annul the results of the second round of the mayoral elections in Chișinău, as upheld by the Moldovan Supreme Court, is questionable, to say the least. International and local observers alike have testified to the fact that fundamental freedoms during the elections were fully observed, prompting concern as to the motivation of this curious move. Andrei Năstase, who won with nearly 53% of the vote, has been involved during the past few years in a number of efforts to uncover corruption and cases of abuses of power at the highest level of office in the state. Concerns that this decision, which could prevent him from taking his elected, rightful office, is politically motivated are not to be easily dismissed – unfortunately. Coming at a time when the country is looking towards parliamentary elections later this year, its implications are of particular concern to this House. In my Group, I therefore support the calls in this resolution to withhold any future disbursements of macro-financial assistance to Moldova under the European Neighbourhood and Partnership Instrument (ENPI) until we have seen the passage of parliamentary elections in line with recognised international standards. I support, of course, Moldovan Euro—Atlantic aspirations, but the country must observe democracy and the rule of law.

name: Rebecca Harms
text: Author. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Mrs Mogherini, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mrs Mogherini, for the work she has done on this report. Following the discussions we have had this week with the opposition and government representatives from Chisinau, Moldova, I expect that large-scale protests will again take place in Chisinau this weekend. First of all, I would like to appeal to the authorities and the government: protect the right to peaceful protest! We have seen similarly strong waves of protests in Armenia and Georgia in recent weeks, and the governments of Armenia and Georgia have shown in an exemplary way that they respect civil rights, that they respect their citizens, and we in the European Parliament expect similar democratic behaviour in Moldova. The rule of law, opposition rights, opposition lawyers' rights, diversity of opinion must be respected in Moldova. We believe that the protests are justified. The annulment of the election of Chisinau was a real shock – not only for the citizens of Chisinau, but also for us. I would recommend that this election be repeated as soon as possible.  I share the decision of the majority of colleagues who negotiated the resolution that the European Commission should suspend the disbursement of macro-financial support. The Government of Moldova should finally take seriously the recommendations of the Venice Commission and the OSCE/ODIHR. We should wait and see whether the parliamentary elections that have been announced in the autumn are conducted in accordance with good democratic rules. And, together with the Moldovan Government, we should finally resolve the banking scandal, this huge fraud. The Prime Minister told me that 80% of them now know where the money that has disappeared is. In cooperation with European police authorities, these assets must be recovered for Moldovan citizens. This should be another condition for macro-financial support.

name: Knut Fleckenstein
text: Author. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which Mr Nesstase, who is here today, has been elected mayor of Chisinau with over 52%. I congratulate him on his election. It is impossible, absolutely impossible, how it has been dealt with. Now we don't like that so much with the judge's scolding. That is why it has wisely been written down differently with "concern". But in a debate it must be allowed to say: this is a scandal. What happened there is far from any proportionality and therefore unacceptable. And if there is someone or a group behind it that has promoted it: if that is the case, it must be clarified, and those – if so – who have done so have not only harmed democracy, they have betrayed their country, which I think was actually on a very good path. That is why what Rebecca Harms said is true: those who protest there must not only be protected as long as they are peaceful, but they must know that this Parliament is in fact standing in the street alongside them mentally. One thing, however – and we differ – is that we do not like turning the financial tap, because I firmly believe that this is something that is damaging to the country and to the citizens of the country. And in reality, no one wants that. That is why we will abstain. But we are fully in line with this concern.

name: Petras Auštrevičius
text: author. – Madam President, in my capacity as a standing rapporteur and as a real friend of Moldova, I must confess that I am standing here feeling totally disillusioned and very sad. Moldova, once called a frontrunner associated partner of the European Union, was the first to receive a visa-free regime and to initiate sizeable reforms in a number of fields. Today, the label that sticks to Moldova is that of a captured state, ruled by a non—transparent political elite, a sort of private company. The judiciary – captured: the court decision on the Chișinău elections is a real ‘theatre of the absurd’, with the call to ‘get out the vote’ suddenly being outlawed. The electoral system – captured: election laws have been twisted and adapted to guarantee seats only to some parties and eliminate others. The banking sector – captured: EUR 1 billion disappears and no genuine effort is made to recover the funds and bring those responsible to justice. Media – captured: the concentration of the media in the hands of only few players, results in a lack of pluralism and in manipulation and disinformation. The free media are struggling for their very existence. All in all, this can only mean that a pro-European Moldova is still just a vision, a long way from reality. I sincerely believe in the EU-Moldovan partnership, as a means of bringing a better future for Moldovans, who deserve our firm support and cooperation.

name: Helmut Scholz
text: Author. Madam President, High Representative, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. Day 31 of the industrial action of our interpreters, for that must also be the time to name it. One might wonder what actually happened to the model country of the Eastern Neighbourhood. My answer is clear: nothing. Moldova's elites have been operating as always, at least for the last ten years. EU diplomats see the country as a failed state, and country specialists characterize it as a state of war. Both assessments have in common: oligarchic cliques rule in Chisinau, whose worldview assumes that not only the economy, but every state institution has to serve them privately exclusively, and every aspect of social life must be subordinated to their interests. We see the result every day: election results are annulled at will, as in Chisinau, election laws are tailored according to needs, political opponents are criminalised, their lawyers are criminally threatened or even forced into political asylum in EU states. In Moldova, violations of fundamental human rights, corruption, abuse of office and arbitrariness of the judiciary go hand in hand with the theft of billions of euros of public money, its cover-up and state unwillingness to investigate. The same game for ten years. Let's finally name Ross and Reiter: Plahotniuc, Filat, Shor, Plato, Usatii. Let us name the Moldova system as it works. Few enrich themselves without limits, while many live in poverty and have to seek their job and future opportunities abroad. Every day they are told by the oligarchs' media monopolies that all this is without an alternative. No, there is an alternative, and that is why we should freeze macro-financial assistance with immediate effect and call on the Commission and the Council to personally sanction the thieves and manipulators.

name: Siegfried Mureşan
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – The decision to annul the democratic elections in Chisinau destroys the whole foundation of the relationship between the Republic of Moldova and the European Union. I want Moldova to come to Europe, along with Romania and other civilized countries, but the authorities have taken the Republic of Moldova to emergency situations, along with Burundi and Somalia. Today, the overwhelming majority of the European Parliament will adopt a decision saying: we cannot provide the Chisinau authorities with 100 million macro-financial assistance. This decision means that there is zero confidence in the Chisinau authorities. Europe will not pretend that things are going well in the Republic of Moldova. We will say things by name, that is: the chisinau authorities are a hindrance to the European Union's desire to help the citizens of the Republic of Moldova. The resolution that we will adopt today is an extremely critical one. Never in recent years has the situation in the Republic of Moldova been so serious, and Europe sees and knows this. We will say things by name and we will be with the citizens. That is why, to the people who demonstrate for European values, I say very clearly: we see you. We're with you. Don't be afraid. You're not alone. [The speaker agreed to answer a question put in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure.))

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: question put in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure. – You said, dear colleague, Mr Mureşan, that we should stand with the citizens of the Republic of Moldova. But how can we stand with the citizens of the Republic of Moldova when we vote for this 100 million not to reach the Republic of Moldova? This money is not for the government of the Republic of Moldova and for the administration of the Republic of Moldova. They are for the citizens of the Republic of Moldova and, if they really – and this is the truth – are historically, ethnically, culturally, from south-eastern European, we must support the citizens of the Republic of Moldova in the first place. Don't you think so?

name: Siegfried Mureşan (PPE)
text: answer to a question asked in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure. – Madam President, it is my great pleasure to speak for another 30 seconds about the citizens of the Republic of Moldova. The citizens of the Republic of Moldova want European values, they want democracy, they want free elections, that's why they take to the streets. They want the rule of law. They want justice that does justice and they see that these authorities are not doing what the citizens of the Republic of Moldova expect: they are not reforming the Republic of Moldova, improving roads, improving schools, improving hospitals. That is why people – and if you talked to people, you would know, Mr Frunzulica – people say very clearly: put pressure on this Government, to finally do what we expect. There are conditions for macro-financial assistance. The money will come when the conditions are met.

name: Victor Boştinaru
text: on behalf of the S&D group – Madam President, Madam High Representative, I want to be explicit: the annulment of the elections in Chisinau, confirmed by three courts in the Republic of Moldova, is a deeply worrying case of non-compliance with the will of the electorate and casts an undeserved shadow over democratic developments in this country.  But to say without evidence, such as the EPP, that the decision was the result of political intervention in the judiciary and, above all, to ask the politician to intervene and change the court's decision is contrary to the rule of law. The government immediately offered to amend the legislation until September to ensure that future parliamentary elections will be free, democratic and transparent. Now, the EPP is proposing to block European funding for this country, risking actually playing the game of Dodon and Russia. I am finally addressing the opposition and the majority in Chisinau. Don't burn the country down! Because after the parliamentary elections, you will have to build together a pro-European coalition government.

name: Anna Elżbieta Fotyga
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, I really appreciate the security policy and, in particular, the transatlantic orientation of the current Government of Moldova. Yet, with all my political experience, I have to raise my voice in defence of Moldovan society and condemn the invalidation of two rounds of mayoral elections in Chișinău. I think the decision was taken on political grounds with clear influence by the oligarchs. That is a matter of concern. In relation to the changes of electoral law, we warned that it was improper. I think that it was the right and proper time to eradicate potential weaknesses in this law, but not to orient it towards achieving political gains.

name: Renate Weber
text: on behalf of the ALDE group. – Madam President, law is the art of good and fairness, the Romans said, and political science tells us that popular voting is the foundation of a democracy and the law is the guarantor of that foundation. Unfortunately, the Moldovan justice system violated the popular will expressed by vote, misinterpreting the electoral law and canceling the vote of the people of Chisinau. Neither good nor equity were found in the decisions of the courts, and the justice system simply made political games. Andrei Nastase, the emphatic winner of the elections in Chisinau, did what each of us does on election day: we invite people to exercise their civic right to vote. Nastase did not mention who to vote for. This is not campaign or electoral propaganda, to which the formula "electoral agitation" refers in Moldovan law. In fact, scared of the victory of the opposition, the real power of Moldova, that is Vladimir Plahotniuc and his cronies, relied on a reliable ally: controlled justice. And it turned to absurd interpretations, with one purpose: to annul the popular will. A political power and a justice that deeply despises its own people – the European Union cannot recklessly witness such mockery of the popular vote. It is time for a firm, if painful, decision: the suspension of the tranches of the macro-financial assistance fund until after the parliamentary elections are properly held.

name: Heidi Hautala
text: On behalf of the Group of the European People's Party (Verts/ALE). – Mr President, just a few years ago Moldova was a model of how well the country is developing towards democracy. There was talk that it is a pioneer in the Eastern Partnership. But it is now quite clear, of course, that the country is a parliamentary state grab and that there more than one party, perhaps also led mainly by the Sister Party of the Social Democrats, has taken over all the power in the hands of an oligarch. The consequence, then, is that the rule of law is being scrapped, which is reflected in the annulment of the mayoral election in Chișinău. We cannot remain indifferent to this. This absolutely must be addressed, because European values are now eroding from within the European Union as well. We have problems in Poland, which we have discussed this week, and we have deep problems in Hungary. We cannot allow European values to be treated in this way. Action must be taken and macro-financial support must also be considered.

name: France Jamet
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, it is clear that since the invalidation of the municipal elections on 3 June in Chisinau, a serious political crisis has been destabilising Moldova.  Straddles the European Union and close to Russia because of its geographical location, history and culture, this country finds itself in a particularly fragile geopolitical situation. Once again, I see that Brussels is interfering in the affairs of a third country. As it happens, the vast majority of the Russian-speaking population is pro-Russian. As it happens, Brussels keeps trying to settle its case with Russia. This attempt to interfere with the Commission is, no more or less, a denial of the right of peoples to self-determination. Just as the Commission has shown with regard to Poland, Hungary or Italy. But what is more serious is that by attracting this region to Romania at all costs, it will take the risk of triggering a crisis with Russia and Ukraine.  The Commission will sow chaos in Moldova and blow on the embers of a potential civil war by dogmatism, by bitterness, by mistake, to settle its accounts with Russia, quite simply.

name: Dobromir Sośnierz (NI).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab In this resolution, you call on the Government in Chisinau to fulfil certain conditions, which are to include recognising the results of the Elections in Chisinau and reforming the judiciary and appointing new judges to prevent the judiciary from interfering in the electoral process. There have not yet been echoes of the fact that Poland was relegated in this House a few days ago for appointing new judges to influence the court, for not respecting the judgments of the courts, and now you are calling on the Government in Moldova to do the exact opposite – that is, to go on the agenda over the judgment of the court and to recognise the results of the elections. What are you really calling for? To appoint judges to rule according to your line? You show your hypocrisy. What else do you Polish something different from Moldova. Maybe someone will explain it to me? Mr Boni speaks for me, maybe he will explain to me what this schizophrenia is? What happens that in Poland it is absolutely necessary to observe the results of the courts, and here it is not?

name: Michał Boni (PPE).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Dear! I will speak Polish. The difference is that in Poland, the term of office of the Supreme Court is interrupted during its duration – which no one talks about in this resolution – and does not break, does not propose a change in democratic principles. Until a few years ago, Moldova was a country on a relatively straight path towards the European Union, accepting the rules of the single market as well as the European backbone of values. However, the apparent political corruption, the opacity of the functioning of the public and private media, the changes in electoral law that build the unauthorised advantage of some, challenged by the Venetian Commission, put moldova's future in great doubt. Recent events, when, after winning a fair democratic battle for mayor of Chisinau, the court has not since cancelled the result of the win, and ultimately upheld this ruling by the Supreme Court, clearly show the disease that is taking place today in Moldova. This is the full politicisation of the judiciary – against which we are in Poland – the essence of which should be independence. It is a question of the rule of law. It's the oligarchy of democracy. Radical decisions need to be made to stop what is wrong with Moldovan politics. Let us do so today in order to reopen moldova's future in the right direction. (The speaker agreed to answer the blue card question (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Anna Elżbieta Fotyga (ECR)
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. – Mr President, i would like to thank the Rapporteur, Mr Schwab During the government of your option, a consultation of the State Electoral Commission took place in Moscow. At that time, they protested in Poland a few weeks later, because the results of the elections were falsified. How would you respond to this?

name: Michał Boni (PPE)
text: answer to the question asked by raising the blue card. – (start of speech outside the microphone) ... the results of the elections have never been falsified and there is no evidence of this other than that of the ruling party. The unfortunate consultation of the State Electoral Commission concerned the introduction of an electronic system, which was, moreover, blocked by government institutions. And the independent Electoral Commission has unfortunately done it by itself. On the other hand, there were no threats to the transparency of the electoral system. Please don't laugh about it. These are threats to the transparency of the electoral system today if the Supreme Court, as in Moldova, is under political pressure. (The speaker agrees to answer the blue card question (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure).)

name: Dobromir Sośnierz (NI)
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. – You have not answered the question of how the Government in Chisinau is to fulfil the condition of recognising the results of the elections, since a final judgment of the court has been reached. How is he supposed to do it? The term of office of the judges is to be interrupted because there are no elections planned at the moment.

name: Michał Boni (PPE)
text: answer to the question asked by raising the blue card. – The resolution contains recommendations and suggestions for a return to a system that will allow for transparency in the making of choices. I do not read the content of this resolution as a breach of the judicial system to be independent, but as a return to an independent judicial system. Please read the text of the resolution carefully.

name: Andi Cristea (S&D).
text: – Madam President, we are discussing Moldova today because the latest developments in Chișinău require our greatest attention. The non-transparent invalidation of the mayoral elections in Chișinău is an issue of the gravest concern for this House and for all of those who have this country and its people close to their heart. Free and fair elections are the foundation of any democracy and so is the fulfilment of all democratic electoral and constitutional procedures and fundamental democratic commitments. We have to think strategically, act rationally and acknowledge that the solution is not decoupling the Moldova wagon from the EU train, or derailing it. High Representative, this is the reason why a decision on our part to suspend budget support – I am not referring to the macro—financial assistance – would be as wrong as invalidating the elections, and would simply add one mistake on top of another.

name: Bas Belder (ECR).
text: Mr President, it is clear that Brussels must turn its back politically on the abuse of power in Chișinău. We must also note that the High Representative, Mrs Mogherini, and Commissioner Hahn have done so very clearly: the back rights against political abuse of power in Chișinău.  However, at the same time, I would also like to stress that we are thinking of European commitment, i.e. humanitarian engagement, for example a Dutch church organisation that comes to the aid of children from weak, poor families with educational guidance, safety, food, that we must not abandon this European commitment with all our criticism of the abuse of power that is taking place in Moldova. After all, this abuse of power goes first and foremost over the backs of Moldovan civil society, and let us above all hold it. I am counting on the wisdom and also the commitment of the European institutions not to lose sight of this humanitarian aspect in this political crisis situation.  (The speaker responds to a "blue card" question (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Maria Grapini (S&D)
text: question put in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure. – Madam President, my fellow colleague, I think everyone agrees that it was an abuse of power. Everyone agrees that the election should not have been invalidated. But do you think we can correct a mistake made towards candidate Nastase - whom I respect and knows, that I met with him during the campaign - with another injustice? Cut the funds? Do we have to confuse citizens with party leaders? We need to give Dodon water to the mill, so he can boast: behold, what has Europe done to you and to win another mandate? Do you not think that we should not suspend the funds, but we must supervise how the rule of law applies in the Republic of Moldova?

name: Bas Belder (ECR)
text: "blue card" answer. Mr Honourable colleague, then you have not understood my speech. I don't think you should play things off against each other. It must be clear that we must maintain our standards, our principles, and at the same time seek the wisdom of not allowing civil society to suffer. Then we will have to cooperate with the Moldovan authorities.

name: Udo Voigt (NI).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Since 1991, we have seen NATO and the European states pursue a strong russian encirclement policy. Moldova is one of them, Georgia and Ukraine – all of these countries are to be snatched from Russia's influence. I am very surprised at where honesty remains here in this House. Where were the calls when Moldova's first directly elected President, Dodon, was deposed by the Constitutional Court in 2017? When did you want to block loans or withhold allocations? Today, Moldova's sovereignty means nothing more than having to beg for loans from the EU, that is to say in the West. Where has the one billion dollars gone, at three billion, with three Moldovan banks? All these things have not yet been clarified. The EU would do well to implement the principle of non-interference in the internal affairs of another state in Moldova as well.

name: Jaromír Štětina (PPE).
text: – Mr President, as a Member of the European Parliament, I would like to underline that the courts’ decision to annul the results of the mayoral elections in the city of Chișinău bear all the signs of political motivation. If that is true, this would be an alarming indication that the state of democracy in Moldova is weakening. It may jeopardise the country’s ambitions for further integration with the European Union.  The massive protests against nullification of the election results show how deeply Moldova’s citizens are afraid for its future. This sentiment has been strengthened by widespread corruption and lack of implementation of much-needed reforms. It is high time to consider personal accountability of Moldova’s officials.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Cristian Dan Preda (PPE)
text: Question asked in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure. – Mr Štětina, dear colleague, what do you think of the fact that, in Moldova, we have a puppet government controlled by the oligarch Plahotniuc, as in a Member State, where the Government of Bucharest is led by a puppet, Mrs Dăncilă, controlled by Liviu Dragnea, twice sentenced to prison? How do you find this situation?

name: Jaromír Štětina (PPE)
text: answer to the question posed by raising the blue card. – I thank Cristiano for this question. It's not a coincidence, it's a general trend. Take the oligarchy in Russia, take the oligarchy in Georgia, take the oligarchy in Moldova, and it's all caused by the imperial politics that my colleague on my left was talking about a moment ago. I think that's just part of the general evolution in the post-Soviet space.

name: José Inácio Faria (PPE).
text: – Mr President, Madam High Representative, I should begin by greeting the Mayor of Chișinău, present today (I do not know where he is). Municipal elections in Chișinău, Balti, were seen as a test for the Moldovan parliamentary elections next November.  The Supreme Court's invalidation of the victory of pro-European candidate Andrei Năstase in Chișinău has led to accusations of Democratic Party interference in the judiciary, triggered a wave of protests in the capital and further deshended the credibility of the rules of the democratic game, which has been shaken as early as 2017, when the proportional system has been replaced by a mixed system that clearly benefits government parties and discriminates against smaller political forces without a parliamentary seat. Ladies and gentlemen, transparency, impartiality and respect for the results of electoral processes are an integral part of the democratic tradition of Europe and the European Union, which must continue efforts of political association and economic integration, including macro-financial assistance, in scrupulous respect for these principles and in the effective implementation of the reform of the judiciary and the fight against corruption , provided for in the association agreement with Moldova.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: – Mr President, High Representative, fellow members, we cannot play with the fate of some states. We cannot play with a country that has chosen a pro-European path. It's our chance now. Yes, I agree with a resolution, but not with unclear wording, let's introduce even new fake news here or uncertainties. What does that mean, writing in a resolution, paragraph 1, that there are dubious things? We have to be very careful and careful when we propose something to a government. Once again, I repeat: I absolutely agree that they should not be cancelled, but we cannot cut this financial assistance for citizens. Are we thinking about the citizens of the Republic of Moldova or are we thinking about a particular person? Therefore, I will not vote for this resolution, and I ask you to understand that by voting on the resolution, we are in fact turning the road of the Republic of Moldova from Europe to Russia.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE).
text: – Mr President, what happened in the Republic of Moldova by invalidating the elections for Chisinau City Hall is unacceptable, even for a emerging democracy. Vox Populi, Vox Dei or "the will of the people is the will of God." Unfortunately, the Russian forces are unable to accept that Andrei Nastase was the chosen of the people, invalidating the elections for non-existent reasons.
