I therefore call on all the European institutions – the European Commission, the Council, but also the European Parliament – to intervene immediately, within the limits of their legal powers, in order to ensure that the will of the people is respected in the Republic of Moldova. The European Union needs a strong Republic of Moldova, where fundamental human rights and freedoms are respected. Its European journey must not be broken by those who do not understand to respect democracy, its values and principles.

name: Julie Ward (S&D).
text: – I have spent some time in the beautiful city of Chișinău, and I know that its citizens want a better society. Therefore, the recent court ruling to invalidate the mayoral elections in Chișinău is very worrying. None of the candidates had complained about the results of the elections but they were cancelled nevertheless, because of a minor offence punishable by a small fine. The court ruling deprives the Moldovan people of their elected candidate and puts democracy in danger. The lack of transparency regarding the decision is also very worrying as it calls into question the independence of the judiciary in Moldova. Moldovan people want to live in a democratic country and they should not be deprived of their right to political participation. As a close partner of Moldova, the European Union should support Moldovan civil society and citizens, and call for the court ruling to be cancelled.

name: Cristian-Silviu Buşoi (PPE).
text: – Mr President, the respect of Moldovan citizens for European values is inversely proportional to that of the authorities that today lead the Republic of Moldova, which are using, more recently, legislative third-party laws as a tool against the exercise of democracy. The consequences of this action affect, as usual, the economic development of the Republic of Moldova and the European future of young Moldovans at home and abroad.  Moldovan citizens need, more than ever, the support of the European Union, and we must give a very clear message that we do not tolerate this situation, in which the will of the citizens of Chisinau, to elect Andrei Nastase as mayor, is overthrown by influencing decisions of the courts. More recently, in the context of the new electoral laws, which violate the recommendations of the Venice Commission and the OSCE office, an equally clear message is needed that legislation that gives equal opportunities to all political competitors must be re-established. Moldova must remain on the path of European values, towards a healthy democracy, towards an independent judiciary, towards the development of the business environment.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Mr President, if the elections are to be annulled, this can only happen on the basis of very strong arguments, and we must say that the decision of the Kishin court is absolutely flat in the argument. However, the situation in Moldova has long been extremely worrying. Moldova is a beautiful country, very good-hearted people live there, and then we have a few names of oligarchs, which are constantly repeated and with which there is boundless robbing.  I think that support for the European Union is kind of disappearing and not getting to the citizens. And the citizens of Moldova deserve our support, because I feel that they profess our values, the values of the European Union. Can we keep quiet today? Well, no doubt we cannot remain silent, because we are with the citizens of Moldova. And that's our main advantage, unlike those oligarchs who aren't with them. So let's please help the people of Moldova. Let us find ways to bypass the oligarchs and support Moldova as such.

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, let me start by thanking Parliament for the attention you always pay to Moldova. I would like to thank the representatives of the opposition in Moldova for their presence here with us today, and also for the opportunity I had to meet with them yesterday. I also met with Prime Minister Pavel Filip just two months ago at our Association Council and I think that our constant attention and the channels which are constantly open with all our interlocutors from Parliament, myself, Commissioner Hahn and all the European institutions are extremely important in terms of accompanying the country onto the right track. I remember, with a lot of emotion and positive memories, when we had visa liberalisation for Moldovan citizens, Moldova being the frontrunner of our Eastern Partnership countries, just a few years ago. After the invalidation of the mayoral elections in Chișinău, as you know, Commissioner Hahn and I reacted immediately. The Supreme Court decision of 25 June deprives the citizens of Chișinău of a democratically elected mayor. Last week, the Central Election Commission decided not to organise new elections and this confirms that Chișinău will continue to be governed by a non-elected administration. These decisions undermine the trust of the citizens of Moldova in the state institutions. The invalidation of the mayoral elections was non-transparent, and we expect – I personally expect – the Moldovan authorities quickly to find a way out of this unacceptable solution and to guarantee judicial independence, in line with Moldova’s international commitments. In all our contacts with our Moldovan interlocutors, we always keep a strong focus on the reforms Moldova needs: addressing the lack of independence of the judiciary, investigating the banking frauds, looking at electoral reform, protecting the space for free media, and we could continue. The European Union has been consistently asking for these reforms, but – and let me stress this very clearly – it is, first and foremost, Moldovan citizens who expect and deserve them. They have been asking for these reforms for years, and I think they expect them to be delivered. In recent weeks the citizens of Chișinău have been expressing their dissatisfaction very clearly through peaceful demonstrations. Their safety, freedom and right to demonstrate must always be respected and guaranteed. This is an absolute priority. I would like to stress – as Rebecca Harms mentioned earlier – that we will keep an eye on what happens in the coming weeks. We expect their safety and freedom to be protected and guaranteed. Journalists must always be allowed to do their job freely. While I am mentioning the press, let me just mention the work we are doing in Moldova through our Strategic Communication Task Force, to support independent media, to monitor disinformation from all sources and to communicate the benefits of cooperation with the European Union. Let me stress very clearly that cooperation with the European Union is not against anyone: it is for the benefit of Moldovan citizens. We do not think in terms of spheres of influence or geopolitics. We think only in terms of reforms, sustainable situations, including on the economic front, and the rule of law and democracy in the countries that are around us. Let me also share with you the news that we will increase our work on communication and media freedom in Moldova, and in other Eastern Partnership countries, thanks in part to this Parliament’s support for all the strategic communications task forces, and in particular the ‘East’ one. Credible, inclusive and transparent elections at all levels are basic pillars of any democracy. The way the mayoral elections in Chișinău have been handled does not bode well for the organisation of the national elections expected at the end of this year. Our position has been very clear since the Council conclusions we adopted last February. The new electoral law that was adopted exactly a year ago does not address the key recommendations of international partners, namely the Council of Europe Venice Commission and the OSCE Office for Democratic Institutions and Human Rights. This is also largely reflected in your motion for a resolution, and all this is why we have decided to put on hold the disbursement of the first tranche after the current macro—financial assistance programme. As you know, disbursements under the macro—financial assistance programme are contingent on two things: not only the successful implementation of specific economic policy measures laid out in the memorandum of understanding – and we consider that these have been implemented – but also the fulfilment of political preconditions related to respect for democratic mechanisms, the rule of law and human rights. Following the invalidation of the mayoral election, the political preconditions have not been fulfilled. In this situation, a decision was taken to put on hold the disbursement of the first macro—financial assistance tranche until the political preconditions attached to our assistance are met. We hope this can happen soon – the sooner, the better – but it must happen. I will personally keep in constant contact with all our interlocutors in Moldova. I hope you will continue to do the same. Parliament can be extremely helpful and useful here, as always. For us, Moldova is not just a neighbour, it is a friend and a partner – Moldovan citizens are – and we will keeping engaging for a positive, fast solution to the current crisis.  (Applause)

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: I close the debate. The vote will take place on Thursday 5 July 2018. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. The debate on 5 July 2018 on Moldova in the European Parliament departs from the real issues: it will only be about electoral quarrels. We will forget the 661 million euros of European subsidies already paid since 2007, and the massive embezzlement of former Prime Minister Vlad Filat. However, he was sentenced in 2016 to nine years in prison for receiving $260 million in bribes from the billion euros "disappeared" from three Moldovan banks. What about the curious hitch of the "EURONEST Assembly" formed by elected representatives of the European Parliament and the parliaments of Armenia, Azerbaijan, Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine. What French taxpayer can accept this concept of European parliamentarians wasting their time in a "Parliament bis" with these countries in the East? This time for debate should be used to discuss the three priorities of Europeans: the fight against jihadism, the control of migration flows and the fight against unemployment.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: The next item is the debate on six motions for resolutions on Somalia (2018/2784(RSP)).

name: Charles Tannock
text: author. – Mr President, last Sunday on the 58th anniversary of Somalian independence, four civilians were tragically killed by mortar attacks in Mogadishu. The next day, seven more were injured by a roadside bomb. Both attacks have been attributed to the Jihadi terrorist group Al-Shabaab. On what should have been a weekend of celebration and hope for the Somalian people, there was more killing, more bereaved and broken families, more fear and terror. For over two decades, these recurring tragedies have blighted the Somali nation. The civil war and unchecked terrorist activities, as well as corruption and mismanagement, have left 80% of the Somali population in dire poverty, with two million living as refugees. The lack of food is a reality for millions on the verge of starvation, but, in spite of all this, under President Mohammed’s government the country is inching towards some stability – but there is still much more work to be done. If Somali security forces are to be up to the task following the withdrawal of the UN Amisom troops in 2020, then state military capability, security and financial governance must be strengthened. The international community and the EU must continue to do what it can to promote lasting stability and peace in this very fragile nation in the Horn of Africa.

name: Bodil Valero
text: Author. Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr As Mr Tannock says, Somalia is making some progress towards more democracy, but the road is very long and it is influenced by a number of factors. After years of drought, for example, the recent torrential rains have forced 130 000 people to leave their homes. It is estimated that half of them are children. Even before, 2.6 million people had been affected by the drought and conflict. The Dadaab camp in Kenya is home to 350 000 people that kenyans would most like to send back, because the international community does not provide adequate support. Many Somalis have also taken refuge in Europe. However, in order to overcome problems, the root causes must be tackled. The main causes are decades of conflict and poverty and both reinforce each other. An increasingly contributing factor is the climate impact that leads to drought and floods. Climate impact has been a clear feature for many years, but is obscured by other more direct and visible problems. Another major problem is impunity, and we therefore welcome the establishment of an independent national human rights commission. We expect all violations to be investigated and the perpetrators prosecuted.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar
text: Author. – Mr President, Mrs Mogherini, in this Plenary of the European Parliament, as always, we deal with the problems and setbacks of fundamental rights, whether in Europe, such as when we discuss the reversal of the rule of law and the separation of powers in Poland or the unacceptable statements by italian Interior Minister Matteo Salvini against Roma or general stigma against foreigners , as if they were a threat to our security, when, in fact, many of them flee terror. Or outside Europe, as is the case in Somalia: terrorist attacks, Al Shabab, continued massacres... a newly elected new democratic situation? No! There were elections in 2018, but there are still many problems that go to fundamental rights ——freedom of association, freedom of expression, freedom of unions—harassment of trade unions and, of course, repression of journalists' freedom of expression.  And, therefore, it is imperative that the European Union make a thorough use of its diplomacy together with the United Nations and the African Union itself to sign the commitment to external action and development cooperation with the mandate to respect and preserve the fundamental rights of all people.

name: Dita Charanzová
text: author. – Mr President, I want to congratulate Somalia on its 58th year of independence earlier this week. However, I would have hoped for it to have taken place under brighter conditions. The security situation remains precarious. More than two million people remain internally displaced. The country is on the brink of another famine. Al-Shabaab is a lesser threat than before, but it is nevertheless still present and is forcibly recruiting children. And despite a new government taking power last year, we have been seeing it gradually take a more autocratic approach with the arbitrary arrests, attacks on journalists, threats and intimidation of trade unions.  This is just naming a few of the many serious problems that Somalia faces today. After decades of conflict, we cannot risk seeing Somalia turn into a failed state or fall into the hands of terrorists. Somalians deserve a better future, and the EU must continue supporting Somalia in any way it can.

name: Michaela Šojdrová
text: author. – Mr President, I would like to express my gratitude to all those who pay attention to the situation in Somalia. This is a typical frozen military conflict. I would like to remember the suffering of millions of people, especially children.  Somalia is a country that has been at the top of the Fragile States Index for the past ten years. The fragility of this country’s alarming state of human rights is not ignored by the EU: the EU has provided EUR 486 million through the European Development Fund, focusing on peace-building, food security and education. Therefore, we need to express our support for such stabilising initiatives and call on local governmental authorities to undertake the appropriate steps in order to mitigate the situation. This country experiences awful terrorism, higher rates of corruption, misusing children as soldiers, extreme poverty, child malnutrition and political instability. We must make sure that a mission funded by the EU implements its mandate fully in order to protect civilians. So I ask you, Madam High Representative, to ensure that the international humanitarian response plan for Somalia is fully developed. I am convinced that this resolution outlines a possible solution to Somalia’s desperate situation. I hope it will be largely welcomed and supported.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey
text: Author. – Mr President, Mrs Mogherini, Somalia is one of the poorest countries in the world and has been mired in a kind of civil war for more than a decade. Clan violence is instrumentalized by external interests, such as Saudi Arabia, one of our main trading partners, unfortunately. Floods and constant droughts aggravate the dramatic situation in the Somali people. Terrorism is being combated with sustainable development, with integration and social cohesion, with redistribution of wealth, as the resolution that we will vote on today, not with militarization, points out. Somalia's stabilization requires an end to the hypocrisy of our foreign policy. Development aid should not be conditional on its complicity in the Union's dire migration policy, which should focus on achieving the sustainable development objectives. But sadly, the biggest spending by far from the international community in Somalia is military. We would not object if drones shared social inclusion and human rights, but we know that, as a product of our political coherence, this is not the case.

name: Pavel Svoboda
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, Somalia has experienced 20 years of civil war, human rights have virtually no place here. There are many Islamist terrorist attacks in the country. At least 512 people were killed in the largest of them in October 2017.  Transparency International considers Somalia to be the country with the highest level of corruption in the world. The International Federation of Journalists considers Somalia to be the most dangerous country in the world. Court proceedings here are often carried out by military courts and often use the death penalty. Somalia is consistently third in the world in the persecution of Christians. The Archbishop of Mogadishu has declared that there can be no Christian in Somalia. 1,200,000 children suffer from malnutrition. Drought and subsequent flooding have forced 230,000 people to leave their homes.  Unfortunately, this is what an almost perfect catalogue of the causes of migration from the African continent looks like. If we want to contribute to eliminating these causes, the European Union must contribute to starting the basic functions of the Somali state, in order to lay the foundations for Somalia's renewed civil society. This should be the objective of the European Union.

name: Francisco Assis
text: On behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, Commissioner Mogherini, ladies and gentlemen, Somalia is, as we know, a country buffeted by violence for too long, multiform violence with various origins and various actors, some state- and other non-state, which affects the population, sometimes directly, sometimes collaterally, through conflicts between wars and territorial disputes, and which does not spare children. Violence is known to be able everywhere to provoke even more violence, and in recent years Somalia has yet to withstand the terrorist attacks of the al-Shabaab militia, a metastasis from al-Qaeda.  Although the Somali Government has taken some steps towards institutional and electoral normalisation, with the support of the international community, and held free elections on 17, the truth is that human, political and civil rights continue to be systematically attacked on a scale with few parallels in the rest of the world. Somalia is now a disstructured state and, as long as it is, it will hardly be able to stop the violence and misery that make the lives of its inhabitants a living hell.  The EU has provided significant financial aid, but it must redouble its efforts to stabilise and structure the country, which also involves convening and holding accountable some Arab countries that have contributed to sharpening political conflict with their conflicting interests.

name: Anna Elżbieta Fotyga
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, decades of civil war in Somalia left an enormous death toll among civilians, and also a very grave humanitarian situation. We support President Mohamed’s resolve to eradicate al—Shabaab’s terrorism. We also support engagement of regional countries like Kenya and Ethiopia in strengthening this resolve. Yet, I think that we have to engage and think about the future, think about withdrawal of AMISOM (the African Union Mission to Somalia) and strengthening our presence, including the EU NAVFOR Somalia (Operation Atalanta) rearrangement after Brexit.

name: Javier Nart
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, I make my own the descriptions that have been made of Somalia, but there is one issue on which no one enters. Somalia is fighting Somalis and, very effectively, the Al-Shabab terrorist militia, but in front of foreigners, as is the case in Afghanistan. The Taliban are the Afghans and the ones who prevent the Taliban from winning are foreigners.  Something is happening when in a place where clans and tribes are extraordinarily effective in war, the only ones who effectively confront Al Shabab are foreigners, and when foreigners leave, they will win the locals, which is the terrorist militia.  We have to do more than just "words." The problem is not to increase foreign units or the presence of the United Nations; the problem is having local actors, because you can't make a war against or without the local people. What we're doing is keeping a dead system in assisted breathing, and in the end, we'll pay for it.

name: Ignazio Corrao
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, Elman Ali Ahmed had a dream: to disarm child soldiers and to end the civil war that has bloodied his country, Somalia, for too many years. The Somali father of peace, faced with forced recruitment, summary killings and mutilation of children, decided to use his life as a shield for children who were victims of madness, thus paying the price of his dream with life itself. So many people like Elman today are fighting and dying to save Somalia from a treacherous war between clans, terrorist groups and government forces. A torn war that does not hesitate to use children as meat for slaughter, in a country now exhausted by drought and disease. We are facing an unprecedented humanitarian crisis in a country where human life continues to be worth very little. In addition, there is repression, the restriction of all freedoms, arbitrary arrests and summary executions at the hands of all parties to the conflict. I hope that the European Union will put immediate pressure on the Somali authorities to stop using the NISA intelligence agency to carry out arbitrary arrests, abuses and torture of suspected terrorists. The NISA urgently needs to be scaled back and regulated by an effective monitoring mechanism to prevent ongoing serious human rights violations.

name: Jacques Colombier
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, the situation in Somalia is terrible, as everyone sees. Carried by four left-wing MPs, this motion for a resolution is, once again, an aggregate of wishful thinking aimed at raising awareness. The elected socialists seem to discover today all the evils of radical Islamism, because that is the problem. Whereas wherever they are in power in Europe, they are the great defenders of multiculturalism and have very little regard for the damage of the Islamization of our societies. A strong proponent of mass immigration, they should first and foremost fight the massive infiltration of jihadists into Europe, deliberately organized by the Islamic State. So, wanting to pacify Somalia remains an illusion, given the state of the country, especially since the action of states and that of murderous Islamist groups cannot be put on the same level. So let the socialist moralizers sweep in front of their doors and stop being complicit in the Islamization of the nations of Europe, as they did or continue to do in Molenbeek, or in Italy yesterday, or in Spain today.

name: James Carver (NI).
text: – Mr President, I would like to say to the High Representative that I never cease to be amazed by some of the proposals that come before this Chamber for discussion. In the case of Somalia, we have before us proposals that would be onerous for a first-world economy to implement, but here we are seriously suggesting that one of the world’s most impoverished states should be concerned with statutory oversight of its security apparatus and protecting the rights of labour unions. Might I respectfully suggest that the priority for both Somali forces and the African Union Mission in Somalia (AMISOM) is to deal with al-Shabaab and other extremist militias, thus ensuring that all Somalis may be able to take part in the democratic process? Even more important to them are food security and access to clean water and education. These self-indulgent proposals bear no relation to the situation on the ground. You seem to hold the Somali authorities to a very high standard, High Representative, much higher than that to which the Spanish Government has been held, for example, who seem to be able to imprison political opponents with impunity. Mr President, why not instead try to help Somalis, as opposed to saddling them with further pointless and irrelevant bureaucratic obligations? (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Julie Ward (S&D)
text: blue-card question. – I wonder if Mr Carver, who is a Brexiter, is aware of the incredible danger to security on the Kenyan and Somali border precisely because of Brexit? We have a very complex arrangement with the Kenyan security authorities, who I spoke to when I visited the British Embassy in Kenya, and they told me about the arrangements that had been made to secure the border of Somalia, thereby ensuring that al-Shabaab terrorists would not come over. These arrangements are to do with paying the stipend of the soldiers and their training, and it is in danger because of Brexit, Mr Carver.

name: James Carver (NI)
text: blue-card answer. – As someone who has visited Somalia on four occasions, I am probably the Member here who has visited the country more times than anybody else and I feel far more qualified to speak in this area. AMISOM of course have huge international support, and it is absolutely ridiculous to suggest that international support will not continue after Brexit. Maybe you might prefer doing it in the name of the European Union; maybe you support European military forces. I doubt that many of your constituents do, Ms Ward, but I take the view that it should be up to national Member States to actually have that important decision with regard to the use of our military forces and whom we support. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D)
text: blue-card question. – Honourable colleague, I understand that fake news has been spread much too often in recent times, and in particular it had a lot to do with the result of the Brexit referendum in the UK, but I just heard you say that the Spanish Government imprisons political opponents with impunity. How can you say that? Are you aware that it was a judicial decision in the first place and nothing to do with the Government’s decision? Are you aware that the grounds are precisely that they have presumably committed criminal offences? How do you dare to spread fake news, live in the European Parliament, with impunity?

name: James Carver (NI)
text: blue-card answer. – As someone who speaks of self-determination, not just for my country with our withdrawal from the European Union and a supporter of Brexit, but also self-determination for countries such as Somaliland, which has been a peaceful breakaway part of Somalia for the last 27 years, I have every right to speak on every issue, I say; and Sir, I can look our Catalonian colleagues in the eyes far better and with far more satisfaction with own soul than I’m sure you can!

name: Wajid Khan (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Somalia is not a safe place for many reasons. Al—Shabaab keep terrorising the population. Human rights defenders, civil society activists and political leaders continue to face threats on a daily basis. Journalists cannot report on the widespread corruption that is tearing through the country. Children are at constant risk of being abducted and used as soldiers or going through severe malnutrition. Somalia is facing extreme challenges – we acknowledge that – and the EU will continue to assist Somalia in improving the living conditions of the most vulnerable, fighting the plight of child soldiers as well as a terror threat that is jeopardising the country’s stability. However the government of Somalia must be willing to work on its human rights record, including guaranteeing the basic freedoms of expression and association, as well as ensuring that those responsible for grave abuses do not walk away with impunity. I know that the Vice—President / High Representative Ms Federica Mogherini is doing a great job, but this area needs her full attention and I am she will do a fantastic job in this area.

name: Julie Ward (S&D).
text: – Mr President, the situation in Somalia has been horrific for several decades. The failure of state institutions has allowed non-state actors such as al—Shabaab to take control over parts of the territory and perpetrate widespread human rights abuses. As I have already said, a situation that will be worsened by Brexit.  Freedom of expression continues to be limited, and policed by the authorities and armed groups. The plight of journalists is particularly concerning because they are under attack from all sides. Somalia is one of the most deadly countries for journalists, with numerous killings often met with impunity. The humanitarian situation is sadly also dramatic as hunger and malnutrition continue to be widespread. The drought has led to the further isolation of women and girls, exposing them to greater risks of sexual violence.  The EU should continue to lead support for the Somalian people, towards security, and our European partnership with Somalia must be based on human rights and it needs to involve women and young people.

name: President. –
text: Mr Carver, I see your blue card, but you have already asked Ms Ward a question. I would like to propose that you do not continue the British-British dispute.

name: James Carver (NI).
text: – Mr President, this is a point on Somalia. This is not a party political point. This is not a point relating to Brexit. This is a political Somalia issue.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: – Mr President, the debate clearly described the disastrous situation in Somalia. We can all agree on that. It's not in our power to resolve this matter at the moment. What we can do is provide humanitarian aid alongside our diplomatic presence.  I would like to ask the High Representative: what is it like with our humanitarian aid at the moment? The resolution refers to specific figures. I want to ask if the help is really real. Whether it ends only with general proclamations and whether the help is effectively used and is really given to those who need it.  Unfortunately, we rarely see money provided to a third country end up in the pockets of the oligarchs' government structures, or humanitarian aid is not provided to those most in need. So please respond to this question.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Mr President, Somalia is paying for the fierce conflict between Saudi Arabia and Qatar. There, conditions of war are developing, in the Somali region, with the recruitment of children, with sexual violence, with the terrorist operation of Al Shabaab. In October 2017, we had 512 dead in its attack, with a total of 2,078 civilian deaths and 2,500 wounded. It is obvious that a peaceful process must prevail and the radical Islamism that is developing in the region must be struck.  Of course, the Somali Government does not have the best accreditations, if you will, on the issue of respect for human rights. It has been accused by the ILO of violating the principle of association, even though it certainly gets EUR 486 million from the European Development Fund. It is obvious that poverty drives and is a fertilizer for terrorism. To support efforts to root out radical Islamism in Somalia.

name: Jean-Luc Schaffhauser (ENF).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I did not intend to intervene, but I still wanted to say two things. On the one hand, the fact that the European Union has chosen to go to Somalia is very courageous. Getting there in an extremely risky place, and despite having stood firm, is a good thing, marks our presence and this one is positive. The second thing, I have already said many times, is that I do not believe that there is a solution to the problem of security and defence without very strong support for the national forces. And this, I remain convinced, with the members of the Security Council who are particularly involved, who have the capacity to intervene and also the means. I think of France, I think of Russia, I think of the United States.  Therefore, I think that, on the one hand, the affirmation of our presence and, on the other hand, the role that we could play in ensuring such coordination would really fulfill our mission of peace.

name: José Inácio Faria (PPE).
text: – Mr President, the civil war has ravaged Somalia for two decades. The continued efforts of the international community to support peace efforts have had little or no results, with clan militias, al-Shabaab and other terrorist groups continuing with impunity to commit terrorist attacks against the Somali government and civilians indiscriminately. But while it is true that Somalis have been suffering from the rise in criminal and terrorist actions by these militias and groups, it is also true, unfortunately, that the sevícias inflicted on the Somali people are also so by the Somali authorities, either through violations and abuses committed against hundreds of children detained by the Somali Government for their alleged terrorist activities , either by limiting freedom of expression, assembly and association, which are fundamental pillars of any democracy. Madam High Representative, respect for human rights, freedom of expression, assembly and association as fundamental pillars of the European Union oblige so, in its joint strategy with Africa, to impose a strict agenda for the defence of human rights as a precondition for any financial assistance.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – A Uachtaráin, aontaím leis an rún seo agus is maith an rud é go bhfuil seans againn aird a thabhairt ar chúrsaí sa tSomáil atá go huafásach i ndáiríre ach ag an am céanna, tá sé tábhachtach go dtabharfaimid aitheantas don rialtas ann atá ag troid i gcoinne constaicí an-mhór ar fad - sceimhlitheoireacht, gorta, caimiléireacht. Agus mar a dúradh, tá raic á déanamh ag Al Shabaab agus caithfear gach cabhar a thabhairt don tSomáil chun buachan orthu. Agus dar ndóigh, nuair a bhíonn caimiléireacht in aon tír is deacair fás geilleagrach a bheith ann ag an am céanna.  Molaim an tAontas as ucht €120 milliún a thabhairt don tSomáil anuraidh chun cabhrú leo troid i gcoinne an ghorta de bharr easpa fearthainne agus caithfimid dul ar aghaidh leis an gcabhair sin a thabhairt don tSomáil. Tá siad ag iarraidh bunreacht nua a thabhairt isteach agus tugann sé sin seans dóibh cearta daonna a aithint.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I think it is extremely unfortunate that there is a national debate against the background of the debate on human rights violations in selected countries, or on certain cases. This is indeed extremely unfortunate, even embarrassing, and I thank the President for ending this debate. There was a Polish debate on both this point and the last point, but it is probably not reasonable.  As far as Somalia is concerned, it is a country of long-term conflicts that have an impact on the civilian population. We are talking about kidnappings, massacres, civil rights as if they do not exist at all, on the contrary, there is impunity, zero rule of law and, of course, no human rights. This is extremely reprehensible and I want to express my condolences to the millions of victims in these conflicts, and I would like to encourage High Representative Mogherini to negotiate with the Somali Government and to try to protect at least the civilian population.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: Thank you very much, Mr President. Thank you for your efforts to limit the British-British debate on non-British issues. (No more room requests)

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, all the speakers made the point very well that the people of Somalia have, for too long, suffered from all sorts of human rights violations. We have terrorist attacks that continue to target the civilian population. The instability has made it much harder for the international community to respond to the extreme weather events that have hit the country – you also mentioned that – adding to a very worrying humanitarian situation. The number of internally displaced people is now close to 2.5 million, with almost another million who have fled to neighbouring countries. I hope that we keep these numbers in mind whenever we talk of an emergency related to migratory flows to Europe. We’re talking about two million people internally displaced in a country like Somalia – more than two million – and another million people who have fled towards other countries. Keep these numbers in mind when we talk about migration in Europe. It is a complex crisis and the European Union has responded to it by mobilising all our different tools. First of all, on the humanitarian side, we stepped up our humanitarian aid to tackle the food crisis and prevent a widespread famine. Some of you asked for concrete figures and numbers and I’m happy to share these. In 2017, we dedicated EUR 130 million to humanitarian interventions alone, on top of the EUR 156 million for development projects. These consistently include human-rights-related indicators, such as inclusion of women and young people. Let me assure you that this money goes directly to projects and that we often visit projects on the ground to check not only that they are real but also that they benefit the local population. I know that some of you have done the same, not only in Somalia but also in other parts of the world where we deploy our massive humanitarian aid and massive development cooperation resources. We have also increased our support for internally displaced people to provide them with shelter, clean water and health care. But humanitarian aid can be effective only if the security situation is under control, and this is definitely not the case in a country like Somalia. Lack of security, extortion and lack of access to certain areas often make it impossible to deliver aid to the people most in need. AMISOM, the African Union peacekeeping operation that the European Union has supported since the beginning in 2007, with more than EUR 1.6 billion, has been essential in providing basic security and will remain key for some time. But I fully agree with those honourable Members who underlined the need to transfer the responsibility for, and ownership of, security into the hands of the Somalis themselves. As long as this has not been completed – and this is our aim, the focus of our effort and our work – it will be superficial somehow. This is why we insist so much on the fact that we will continue to support AMISOM and will continue to be the core element of support for the African Union presence there. But we want to see a transfer of responsibility, including in operational terms, to the security forces of Somalia. This is the only way to have sustainable security and peace in the country. In support of Somali state building, three of our military and civilian missions are currently deployed to Somalia. Not operation Sophia but Operation Atalanta is our presence at sea; and today we are cooperating very closely with the federal government and the federation member states in support of the transition plan so that the Somalis can increasingly take responsibility for their own security. As I mentioned, this is our primary aim. Our engagement with the Somali Government is aimed at empowering them to ensure peace and security in their own country without having to rely on foreign troops forever, but our engagement with the Government goes well beyond security. We are working on women’s empowerment, the rule of law and human rights, which are essential to build sustainable security, sustainable peace and development. We are also, obviously, very much aware that freedom of expression in Somalia is under pressure and we provide financial support to Somali organisations promoting the work of the Somalian media. As you know, the new Government has put forward a broad reform agenda on security, economics and inclusive politics that should lead to the increased participation of women, continued judicial reform and finalisation of the constitutional review, among other issues. It is for the sake of human rights in Somalia that we must accompany and support these reforms. For those reasons, in a couple of weeks from now, on 16—17 July, the European Union – and I personally – will co-host and co-chair the Ministerial Somalia Partnership Forum in Brussels. We will focus precisely on the Government’s reform agenda, security, inclusive politics and economics, and in addition we will hold three side events, one on women’s participation (not least in this building), one on internally displaced people and one on private-public partnership. I believe this will be a very important moment, to show not only our support but also the international support for the efforts that have been made in Somalia. As all the speakers mentioned, the situation there is incredibly difficult, but I can see that the people of Somalia have not lost hope. They want to turn the page and, let me tell you, they clearly count on us, the European Union, to be the partner – not one among the partners but the partner, as colleagues in this Chamber have emphasised – that can accompany this change. We are probably the only ones who can do this successfully. We have an interest in doing it and a responsibility to do it. With our support and with Parliament’s constant engagement, I believe the Somalis can take the future of the country into their own hands.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: I close the debate. The vote will take place on Thursday 5 July 2018. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Mario Borghezio (ENF)
text: in writing. Turkey in Africa is growing stronger and stronger for economic, political and military and defence reasons. For years Turkey has played a major role in Somalia's economic and social recovery by rebuilding the port and airport of Mogadishu as well as lighting and paving its roads. Ankara wants to preserve and extend the Somali model as it can be an example of what Turkey would be able to do in other African countries. It also inaugurated the largest military training center. Somalia is the largest international recipient of the Turkish presence and a military satellite that thus increases Ankara's visibility in the security sector and its presence in the Indian Ocean. Turkey intends to increase its influence by using its cultural and religious ties with several Muslim-majority Regions of Africa. Another point of interest for Turkey is the militarisation of the east coast of Africa in order to gain control over the trade routes. Does the VP/High Representative intend to take action to ensure that Africa, and Somalia in particular, does not become a land of influence, if not military conquest by Ankara? Can you specify how much Turkish investment in Somalia amounts to?

name: Bogdan Brunon Wenta (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Despite the determination of President Mohamed and his government to carry out economic, political and security reforms, and despite their commitment to the process of strengthening the rule of law and stability in Somalia, the level of security in the country is very low. Al-Shabaab and other terrorist organisations are committing bomb attacks and kidnappings. It is condemnable that children are recruited by the Somali armed forces. This constitutes a serious violation of international human rights and the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child ratified by that country.  Somalia is also experiencing one of the most prolonged humanitarian crises in the world, and it is therefore necessary to improve the living conditions of the most vulnerable groups in society and to address the problems of migration, food insecurity, epidemics and natural disasters.  I call on the Somali authorities to strengthen their efforts to protect human and citizen rights and to carry out reforms of the justice and security sectors. The peace and peace process in Somalia must continue to be supported by all international actors involved to help build the stability of the country. The recruitment and exploitation of children by security forces, armed groups and terrorists is a violation of the law, and those responsible for recruiting children must be held accountable.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: The next item is the debate on six motions for resolutions on Burundi (2018/2785(RSP)). At the beginning I have the following message for you. It is scheduled 27 minutes for The High Representative's speeches and parliamentary speeches without taking into account the blue card and catch-the-eye, 27 minutes, that is, we would have finished 4 minutes before 12.00. At 12.00 they are voting. I address you. No blue card. No catch-the-eye. Because the last 5 minutes are entering the room, so our debate also makes very limited sense. And also a request for a very thorough adherement to the time regime.

name: Mark Demesmaeker
text: Author. Mr President, the migration crisis that is building up the EU has several causes. Burundi is ranked among the top 5 African countries from which people are on a perilous journey to Europe. Why? In the "UN-happiness report" of 2018, Burundi dangles in last place. EU resolutions and international reports on human rights violations and repression do not deter President Nkurunziza. In the last few months, 500 Burundians were killed. Since 2015, 400 000 people have been living in refugee camps. Many dream of a life in freedom and security and look to the north, at us.  The prisons are bulging with human rights lawyers and journalists. Those who fear a critical voice are relegated to an authoritarian regime and are sliding into dictatorship. That's where the roots of migration lie.  I therefore expressly call for the release of human rights activists Germain Rukuki and Nestor Nibitanga. Nkurunziza threatens to go down the history books as a dictator unless, under pressure from the international community and the EU, he re-energized his presidency.

name: Maria Arena
text: Author. Mr President, since April 2015, Burundi has fallen into a serious humanitarian crisis, a human rights crisis, but also a political crisis.  Since Mr. Nkurunziza's third term came into force, 593 people have been murdered and there are 600,000 refugees or displaced persons inside or outside Burundi.  The new constitutional revision further strengthens this power and this authoritarian regime, which eliminates any political opponent and threatens its people on a daily basis. The UN Commission of Inquiry denounced increased violence, arbitrary arrests, torture and hate speech. The list of journalists and political opponents now in prison is growing. Therefore, we call on the Commission and the European External Action Service to continue the pressure on the Burundian government, as well as to maintain humanitarian aid to the internal and external populations of the country today, to work with the African Union and the East African Community to support this strategy, to demand the release of political prisoners. , to demand prosecution and to prevent funding for peacekeeping missions from funding the current government of Burundi.

name: Ignazio Corrao
text: Author. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, how much is the word given by a man like Pierre Nkurunziza worth? That is what everyone in Burundi is asking for: civil society, opposition but also ordinary citizens. In fact, the president has stated that he will not run in the next elections in 2020, despite the fact that he could do so precisely thanks to the constitutional referendum that he strongly wanted and won last May, a referendum that made constitutional changes that would allow him to continue to be the highest office of the state for two more seven-year legislatures and therefore until 2034. All this is happening in a country that continues to be pervasive by chaos: the referendum process itself has seen more shadows than lights, with the Imbonerakure militias busy escorting citizens to seats, urging them to vote yes, a recommendation that is difficult to ignore in a country where arbitrary arrests, torture and extrajudicial killings are the order of the day. More than 1 200 dead and hundreds of thousands of civilians fleeing prompted the International Criminal Court last year to open an investigation into events in Burundi. The answer was not long in coming: Burundi, precisely in order to avoid such an investigation, became the first country in history to withdraw from the Rome Statute. The Committee of Inquiry into Burundi, presenting its report to the UNITED Nations Human Rights Council, listed all the violations found and pointed out that the situation continues to be extremely worrying and that the Burundian authorities do not cooperate with the United Nations. Therefore, ladies and gentlemen, commenting on Nkurunziza's statements, I believe that trust is good but not trusting is better. We must continue to talk and deal with Burundi, keep up the pressure, not close our eyes to a tragic situation that has continued continuously since 2015. We need new sanctions against all those who continue to violate human rights in that country; additional controls of the funds are needed to ensure that they do not fall into the hands of the Government and the Burundian authorities but only benefit the population and civil society.

name: Louis Michel
text: Author. Mr President, Madam High Representative, Pierre Nkurunziza's regime is simply a despotic regime, it is an abominable dictatorship. The constitutional referendum was neither free nor transparent, nor independent and therefore certainly not democratic. A blind and savage crackdown has taken place on those who campaigned against constitutional reform. What is more serious is that Pierre Nkurunziza does not respect at all and made a definitive cross on the Arusha agreements, which had been led by Mandela. So I hope that sooner or later he will be held accountable to the Criminal Court - if he does not have to give it back, then I do not know who will have to answer for it. I would like to ask you an extremely specific question on a specific issue that relates to how the European Union is helping Burundian refugees. A request for assistance has been made to enable the 500 to 600 Burundian students to continue their studies in Kigali with the support of the Rwandan authorities. However, I am told that this aid would have been refused on the basis of an opinion of your representative in Burundi, who would consider that it would annoy Mr Nkurunziza. So that's it, I asked you this question very specifically, it embarrasses me to ask you and I would like you to inform us on that. This is the association Maison Shalom, created by Marguerite Barankitse, which has received international awards for its humanitarian work, and which is denied assistance for these 500 students and 70,000 Burundian families who are refugees in Rwanda.

name: Joachim Zeller
text: Author. Mr President, High Representative, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her work and for the work she has While a high-level delegation from the East African Community recently assured UN Secretary-General Guterres that Burundi is on a path of stabilisation following the political unrest since 2015, a United Nations-appointed commission of inquiry into the situation in Burundi comes to a different conclusion: political violence, arbitrary arrests, extrajudicial executions, hate speech and violations of civil and human rights are the order of the day. The president's youth organisation, Imbonerakure, has a free hand in oppressing people, freedom of the press has been abolished, journalists are being murdered, imprisoned or forced to leave the country because they are threatened with life and limb – as well as more than 400 000 people who have so far fled to neighbouring countries and have to live a miserable life there. Nearly four million people in Burundi themselves are in need of humanitarian aid from abroad. Many foreign donors have stopped providing direct financial support to the world's fifth-worst country, so that the money does not end up with those responsible for The Dictatorship in Burundi, President Nkurunziza and his entourage. The intolerable conditions in Burundi are also increasingly a major problem for neighbouring countries. In addition to the refugees, there are growing reports of armed gangs from Burundi raiding villages, for example in Rwanda. Elections are to be held in Burundi in 2020. Nkurunziza is said to have said that, contrary to earlier intentions, he no longer wants to run. Elections, however, only make sense if they are prepared under international supervision, if the repression of the opposition forces ceases immediately and the political prisoners are freed.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat
text: Author. Mr President, this is the sixth resolution on Burundi since April 2015, when President Nkurunziza announced his intention to run for re-election. Since then, the crackdown has intensified, taking on a new dimension with the constitutional referendum in May 2018. There are no longer any imprisoned human rights activists sentenced to long prison terms, restrictions on freedom of association and restrictions on freedom of association and restrictions on the freedom of the press. The UN Commission of Inquiry denounces political violence, arbitrary arrests and extrajudicial executions. The Imbonerakure, the youth of the ruling party league, are increasingly militarized and radicalized. They are the main culprits in this rise in violence and abuse. The fragile Arusha agreements are under threat more than ever, in particular because of the ethnicization of the political crisis. The Burundian population is the first victim. 65% of people live below the poverty line, while the country, like many others in the region, is rich in its basement.  The European Union has taken individual sanctions. It decided to suspend its direct payments to the Burundian government. Whose act. There is an urgent need to act, to act before the 2020 elections and to do everything to ensure that President Nkurunziza finally sticks to his word not to run again. Only a political process involving all stakeholders can help. That is where we need to work together.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, Mrs Mogherini, I usually prefer that these urgent resolutions concern only one case and when we can help one person or group of people get out of prison or from a difficult situation. However, the situation in Burundi is so serious that we have to focus on the whole state. We are witnessing a huge political, human rights and humanitarian crisis. The crisis has escalated into huge unrest, resulting in hundreds of casualties, hundreds of thousands of refugees, hundreds of forcibly displaced people. And the thousands of people who are bearing the fate of this bloody conflict today. Outside civilians, journalists, activists, political opponents are systematically attacked, drawing attention to the current government's practices and strengthening power and intimidation. I therefore call on you, Mrs Mogherini, to deal intensively with this situation.

name: Soraya Post
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, the people of Burundi have experienced a huge crisis in recent years. Not only have we seen worrying changes to the country’s constitution, and tremendous violence surrounding the referendum, but Burundian civil society is also under threat. Since 2016, Burundi has banned six human rights organisations from operating in the country, as well as many media outlets. Human rights defenders are being punished for doing their legitimate work. In April, human rights defender Germain Rukuki was sentenced to 32 years in prison. We know that those in detention can face sexual violence and torture, and he is just one example of many. The EU Member States, including the delegations and embassies on the ground, need to step up support for civil society in Burundi and call strongly for the release of all jailed human rights defenders.

name: Dita Charanzová
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, Burundians are living in a state of fear. Security forces and youth party members have been killing, raping, abducting, torturing and intimidating anyone they believe to be opponents. While the President has finally stated that he will not run for another term, what happened in the run-up to this referendum cannot be forgotten. A government that allows these atrocities to be committed, against real or perceived opponents, has no legitimacy to represent the citizens. A referendum that takes place in such conditions cannot be considered to represent the will of the people. If the Government is truly to show good intentions, it must resume cooperation, in full, with the UN Commission of Inquiry and allow for an independent investigation into all the abuses committed. Talks must be resumed between the Opposition and Government as a matter of urgency, and the EU should actively support this.

name: Bodil Valero
text: Mr President, on behalf of the Group of the Greens/European Free Alliance, I would like to take Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr We fully agree with the criticism of the Burundian regime and its continued violations of human rights, and with that, I would like to go on to talk about the role of the European Union in the country. According to the European Network for Central Africa, the EU is contributing substantial sums to the financing of the Burundian regime, despite sanctions. The grants go through the back door via AMISOM and the African Peace Facility, as the Burundian regime forces its soldiers to pay 20 percent of their salaries to the state treasury. I would like the EEAS to find a solution to the problem. This is an unwanted and problematic consequence when we connect security and development to each other. In paragraph 6 of the resolution, we commend the host countries for their efforts to house the Burundian refugees and we call on them to ensure that the return of refugees is voluntary, based on informed decisions and implemented in a safe and dignified manner. I assume that this also applies to those Burundians who have taken refuge in Europe, and where far from all are granted asylum. The situation of dissidents in Burundi is not new, yet Burundians with the help of Frontex have over the years been forcibly expelled in chartered planes from several countries in Europe...  (The President took the floor from the speaker).

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, since 2015 almost half a million people have fled Burundi and this year, predictably, they will be even more so. Agricultural production has declined, prices have risen and basic services have been cut. In addition, the government systematically suppresses civil society and violates its human rights, while suppressing any political opposition. That is why I am concerned that UNHCR's Burundi plan has received only 21% of the funds it needed for 2017. We regret that Burundi has withdrawn from the International Criminal Court and call for the establishment of a political dialogue between the parties, the release of political prisoners, the reopening of the media and the oenegés and the neighbouring States ensuring the safe return of refugees under the principle of willfulness for each person. Finally, in the context of the humanitarian and migration crisis, we call for the granting of refugee status to any asylum seeker from Burundi.

name: Margot Parker
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, Burundi teeters on the edge. A return to the barbarity of the civil war must be avoided. Instability in Burundi risks spreading to the immediate neighbourhood, especially with repeated attacks in bordering Rwanda, originating from within the country. However, there are no easy solutions. Human history has shown that, of all systems man has devised, democracy offers the greatest wealth and security for all. It is imperative that Burundi continues to develop a thriving democracy, despite the actions of the President in extending his term and modifying the country’s constitution to allow him to retain powers into the 2030s, after a referendum that may not have been conducted freely. His commitment not to seek another term beyond this one is helpful. The decision is not quite a resolution to the issue, but it looks to be moving in the right direction and, hopefully, we will begin to move away from the instability that has plagued Burundi since 2015.

name: Jean-Luc Schaffhauser
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, in Burundi a mechanism of war, with a possible genocide, is in the process of being engaged. It is not the work of the legitimately elected government, which nevertheless represents a large part of the population. It is the result of a thinly veiled attack on Rwanda's neighbour. After his bloodthirsty and genocidal achievements in the Great Lakes, President Kagame wants to regain control of Burundi. His technique is simple, it is proven: inter-ethnic tensions are raised, and then, when the government wants to restore its authority, we cry out for possible genocide to invade the country. It was the Kagame method of invasion, which also changed the constitution to be a dictator for life. We must not allow ourselves to be manipulated by sanctions that people still suffer, while the tyrant of Kigali is rehabilitated. We must accompany a hard and difficult process of democracy.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Mr President, a political, human rights and humanitarian crisis has plagued Burundi since the re-election for a third term of their President in 2015. Thousands have been killed, thousands have fled the country, thousands are displaced and millions are in need of humanitarian assistance. The recent constitutional changes voted for in the 2018 referendum include, for example, expanding presidential powers and prohibiting political parties with less than 5% of the vote from participating in government. This is a great threat to the peace and reconciliation that Burundi has been working towards. Violence has significantly increased – not surprisingly, I suppose – as a result of this referendum campaign and the ensuing result. The repression of views is ever increasing. Many human rights defenders have been detained – some for as long as 32 years – and this is all happening as we speak. I think it is right that we should raise our concerns here in Parliament and hopefully help to bring about a resolution.

name: Neena Gill (S&D).
text: – Mr President, the humanitarian situation in Burundi is alarming. The period of the constitutional referendum has aggravated the tendency of violence and threats in the country. Opponents of the constitutional reform have faced torture, execution and continuing threats and intimidation. Political and ethnic polarisation are now tearing apart the integrity of the army, posing another major threat to Burundi’s stability. My questions to the High Representative are as follows. Firstly, what is the EU doing to support the East African Community to revive an inclusive and political dialogue, as this is the only way to find a lasting solution to the crisis? Secondly, how is the EU supporting refugee camps and settlements, in particular in Nyarugusu in Tanzania, where the number of refugees has grown three times beyond the intended capacity? Thirdly, how does the EU support the 3.6 million people inside Burundi who are in need of humanitarian aid? Finally, High Representative, I urge you not to mistake President Nkurunziza’s statement, made in support of his successor after the referendum, as a clear and firm commitment not to run.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D).
text: – Mr President, even though so much has been achieved since the Arusha agreement, I have to express deep concern regarding the existing political and human rights situation in Burundi, which undermines any initiative for reconciliation, peace and justice. Since April 2015, Burundi has been going through acute political, human rights and humanitarian crises, which have so far led to the death of 595 persons, while another 3.6 million are in need of humanitarian assistance. Therefore, I welcome the European Union’s humanitarian actions in this regard and I consider that we must maintain support for the population affected. It is crucial that this aid be provided in a direct manner to those in need. Violence and intimidation against political opponents, human rights defenders and NGOs must end, as well as the continued degradation of media space and press freedom.  I will conclude by underlining that we should step up our efforts all together.

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, as all the speakers have pointed out, this is a very difficult month for the people of Burundi, with more violence inflicted on a population that has already suffered too much. In April, the Council assessed that there was no reason to change its decision on appropriate measures, as per Article 96 of the Cotonou Agreement. This means that, although we continue to support the people of Burundi through partners on the ground – and I want to reassure you on that point – we have suspended direct financial support to the administration of Burundi. The country remains the only one to have effectively withdrawn from the International Criminal Court, as some of the speakers pointed out, and this decision has come together with a deterioration of the situation in the country. On 17 May, a constitutional referendum was held in a climate of intimidation and repression. Political freedoms are being disregarded. Arbitrary arrests and extra-judicial executions have become common, a situation that we had already denounced before the vote, and we have also called on the authorities of the country to respect the spirit and the letter of the Arusha peace agreement. Last week, on 27 June, the Commission of Inquiry on Burundi briefed the UN Human Rights Council in advance of the submission of its final report in September and, according to the Commission, the ruling party’s youth wing bore the main responsibility for human rights violations during the referendum campaign, with the complicity or approval of state officials. After the referendum, the President indicated that he would not run for the post again in 2020, after 15 years in office. But the announcement, as some of you mentioned very clearly, will need to be followed by an opening of political and public space. The next important political step would be an inclusive dialogue focused on delivering credible elections in 2020. I agree with those of you who underlined the key role of regional players in mediating and facilitating this process, and we give them all our support. Back in 2000, the Arusha agreement gave hope not only to Burundi but also to the entire region, and it is urgent now to go back to the spirit of that agreement and to preserve the country as an inclusive and democratic home for all its people. It is what we will continue to work for, together with the United Nations, the African Union and the East African Community. Let me answer specifically two questions that were raised. Nina Gill asked about our humanitarian aid, focusing mainly on the refugee response. It has amounted to about EUR 8 million in the course of this year, with relatively limited humanitarian support within Burundi and the major effort outside the country, for refugees.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: I close the debate. The vote will take place on Thursday 5 July 2018 (The meeting was suspended at 11.56 am pending the vote.) Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. – I welcome the decision suspending direct financial support to the Burundian administration for violations of human rights, democratic principles and the rule of law. But we must continue to provide direct assistance to the people of Burundi through investments in projects, as a third of them are unable to feed their family today.  More than 400,000 people have fled Burundi to seek refuge in neighbouring countries for civil liberties violations and the rule of law. We cannot support a Government that withdrew from the Rome Statute and thereby suspended the jurisdiction of the International Criminal Court, the government that sentenced Germain Rukuki, employed by the Association of Catholic Lawyers, to 32 years in prison on false charges.  In Burundi, in 2011, a nun, Lucrecija Mamic, who ran the Center for Underalnourished Children and cared for more than 1,500 children, was killed in a monastery. She gave her life helping the people of Burundi who deserved freedom, equality, returning to their homes as well as our full support. Let's not let her sacrifice be in vain.

name: President. –
text: Ladies and gentlemen, if I may ask you kindly to take your seats, we will proceed with the votes. Before I do so – and I would appreciate a second of silence – today is Ellen Heinemann’s last day. She has been working for Parliament, including serving this plenary, for the last 25 years, mostly working on the Minutes and making sure that the texts adopted are correctly published. I must say that she is one of those persons who are not necessarily visible but without whom we would hardly be able to conduct our work. (Applause) So warm thanks, on my behalf and of course – as I am sure you can hear the applause – also from other colleagues.

name: President. –
text: The next item is the vote.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: – Mr President, on behalf of the EPP Group, I suggest an oral amendment to paragraph 10. At the end we would add the following ‘urges AMISOM to fully implement their mandate to protect the civilian population’.

name: Axel Voss
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, I would like to thank the We have all had intensive discussions, but what is this reform about? It is about ending the exploitation of European artists that is taking place on the Internet. We are talking about the major US platforms such as Google and Facebook, which have been making huge profits for years, at the expense of European creatives. We should not accept this any further, and I am completely inexplicable as to how this extreme Internet capitalism can actually be promoted by some. (Applause) While the others call America first, abuse our data and exploit our artistic content, we should slowly start to stand alongside our European creatives, protecting our values. Otherwise, there is a risk of creative insolvency. However, this reform is also about balancing existing law – namely copyright and the fundamental right to property – and not opening the doors to cultural theft as much as possible. What is the point of avoiding copyright infringement? What is the objection to us wanting fair remuneration for journalists, publishers and artists? And what is the point of large platforms having to take more responsibility? The extreme campaign of Google, Facebook and Amazon that we are currently facing, which are being carried into the house, that even affects children of Members of Parliament because they are being called – all of this is based on lies. You will not find any impairments for the individual user. Everyone can continue to set their links, everyone can continue to carry out their uploads with legal certainty, and for the first time the individual is no longer liable for copyright infringement. (Applause)

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, a point of order under Article 158 of the Rules of Procedure. First of all, I would like to express our solidarity here with the just fight of the interpreters and I would like to tell you, Mr President, that at the time we vote the text is not available... (The President withdraws the floor to the speaker)

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I want to thank everyone for the work they’ve done on this important file. We are all united in our shared mission to protect artists and cultural diversity in Europe and I speak as rapporteur in the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection (IMCO), which is the only Committee to share joint competency on one of the most controversial articles – Article 13.  In our Committee we were able to reach a broad compromise that makes meaningful progress on the value gap while at the same time safeguarding the rights of European Internet users, SMEs and start—ups. I deeply regret that the IMCO position has not been taken into account and the text of the Committee on Legal Affairs (JURI) does not achieve the needed balance.  There are real concerns about the effect of Article 13 and freedom of expression, raised by experts ranging from the UN Special Rapporteur, David Kaye, to the inventor of the World Wide Web, Sir Tim Berners-Lee, and there are real concerns voiced by our citizens. Just yesterday I received a petition signed by almost a million people against the JURI Committee mandate.  (Murmurs of dissent followed by interjection by the President) Although there is consensus about the goals behind this law, huge controversy still exists about the methods proposed. Something is not right here. We owe it to the experts, stakeholders and citizens to give this directive the full debate necessary to achieve broad support.  I ask you to refuse to fast—track this law to allow for a broad fact-based debate in September. Please reject the mandate and vote against the JURI proposal.  (Loud applause)

name: György Schöpflin
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, the European Citizens’ Initiative (ECI) is an EU instrument intended to bring citizens closer to the European Union. If a million people sign an initiative then the Commission can be invited, I stress that word, to launch legislation. Parliament has an input into this process in that it holds hearings and – this is the point of contention – plenary debates. The Commission published a new draft regulation about a year ago and would like this to come on stream in 2020. I prepared a thorough and cogent report. My grateful thanks to all who helped. I’ve had numerous discussions with the Commission and with stakeholders. The Committee on Constitutional Affairs (AFCO) voted for this text with a convincing majority. I am asking you today to give me a mandate to begin interinstitutional negotiations. I would like to add here that the Council is well disposed towards these negotiations. It’s a significant window of opportunity. You will all have received a massive input from a group of NGOs demanding that you deny me a mandate, basically because my text does not contain a commitment to holding a plenary debate. This demand is based on a serious error of understanding to the effect that a legislative text can change this House’s Rules of Procedure. No, this is a breach of our internal rule of law, our checks and balances. If I am denied a mandate, as the NGOs are demanding, the whole process will come to a halt and a favourable moment will have been lost. So I am asking you to vote in favour of my mandate. If you do so, I shall initiate an amendment to the Rules of Procedure (under Rule 227) to amend Rule 211 so as to ensure that plenary debates are held on successful ECIs. I’m delighted to say that I have the full support of the S&D Group, so please vote ‘yes’.

name: Günther Oettinger
text: Member of the Commission, in writing. – : Joint statement Joint Statement on the discharge procedure and the date of adoption of the final EU accounts "The European Parliament, the Council and the Commission will – in cooperation with the European Court of Auditors – set out a pragmatic calendar for the discharge procedure.  In that context, the Commission confirms that it will strive to adopt the EU consolidated annual accounts for the financial year 2017 by 30 June 2018 provided that the European Court of Auditors transmits all findings concerning the reliability of these EU accounts, and all consolidated entities' accounts, by 15 May 2018, and its draft annual report by 15 June 2018. The Commission also confirms that it will strive to provide its replies to the European Court of Auditors' Annual report for the financial year 2017 by 15 August 2018 provided that the European Court of Auditors transmits its draft observations to the Commission by 1 June 2018." Commission unilateral statements Statement in relation to Article 38 Publication of information on recipients and other information “The Commission will support through networks with the Member States the exchange of good practices as regards the publication of information on recipients of Union funds implemented under shared management. The Commission will take into due consideration the lessons learnt in view of preparing the next Multiannual Financial Framework." Statement of the Commission on MFF (single set of rules) "The Commission underlines the importance of making progress in the post-2020 multiannual financial framework towards a single set of rules governing the same type of operations irrespective of the way these operations are implemented". Declaration of the Commission in relation to Article 234(1) regarding the creation of thematic Trust funds "Despite the concerns expressed by the Commission during negotiations, Article 234(1) of the Financial Regulation requires that any decision to establish thematic EU Trust-Funds be submitted to the approval of the European Parliament and the Council. The Commission considers that such a decision falls within the scope of Article 317 TFEU, since it concerns budgetary implementation.
